{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} '''Antibiotic use in livestock''' is the use of [[antibiotics]] for any purpose in the [[animal husbandry|husbandry]] of [[livestock]], which includes treatment when ill (therapeutic), treatment of a batch of animals when at least one is diagnosed as ill (metaphylaxis, similar to the way bacterial meningitis is treated in children), and [[preventive healthcare|preventative treatment (prophylaxis)]]. The use of subtherapeutic doses in [[animal feed]] and water<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Cite document|url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/AnimalVeterinary/GuidanceComplianceEnforcement/GuidanceforIndustry/UCM216936.pdf|title=The Judicious Use of Medically Important Antimicrobial Drugs in Food-Producing Animals|last=|first=|date=2012|journal=Guidance for Industry|pages=|via=|publisher=FDA Center for Veterinary Medicine|issue=#209}}</ref> to promote growth and improve [[feed conversion ratio|feed efficiency]] is discouraged by the FDA as part of their Veterinary Feed Directive, which seeks voluntary compliance from drug manufacturers to re-label their antibiotics.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.avma.org/KB/Resources/Pages/VFD123.aspx|title=Veterinary Feed Directive (VFD) Basics|last=|first=|date=|website=AVMA|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://beef.unl.edu/veterinary-feed-directive-questions-and-answers|title=Veterinary Feed Directive Questions and Answers|last=University of Nebraska, Lincoln|first=|date=October 2015|website=UNL Beef|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}}</ref> This article does not cover all these areas and instead focuses on the use of antibiotics for growth promotion, which has been banned in Europe since 2006<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-05-1687_en.htm|title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - Ban on antibiotics as growth promoters in animal feed enters into effect|work=europa.eu}}</ref>, and on legislation regarding antibiotic use in farm animals in the USA.
In 2013, the CDC finalized and released a report detailing antibiotic resistance and classified the top 18 resistant bacterium as either being urgent, serious or concerning threats. Of those organisms, three (''[[C. diff]]'', [[Carbapenem-resistant enterobacteriaceae|carbapanem-resistant enterobacteriaceae]], and ''[[Neisseria gonorrhoeae]]'') have been classified as urgent threats and require more monitoring and prevention. In the US alone, more than 2 million people are diagnosed with antibiotic-resistant infections and over 23,000 die per year due to resistant infections.<ref>Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2016). Antibiotic/Antimicrobial Resistance. Retrieved from https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/ (accessed 5.5.16).</ref>
Given the concerns about antibiotic use for feed conversion, [[#Research into alternatives|research into alternatives]] is ongoing.
==History== In 1910 in the United States, a meat shortage resulted in protests and boycotts.<ref name="Ogle2013">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/2013/09/03/riots-rage-and-resistance-a-brief-history-of-how-antibiotics-arrived-on-the-farm/|title=Riots, Rage and Resistance: A Brief History of How Antibiotics Arrived on the Farm|last=Ogle|first=Maureen|date=3 September 2013|work=[[Scientific American]]|accessdate=5 November 2013}} </ref><ref>Reported locally in these: *"To Become Vegetarians", Mansfield (O.) ''News'', 17 January 1910, p2 *"150,000 at Cleveland Stop the Use of Meat" Syracuse ''Herald-Journal'', 25 January 1910, p1 *"Boycott on Meat is Rapidly Spreading; Men Who Are Blamed For High Price", Atlanta ''Constitution'', 25 January 1910, p1</ref> After this and other shortages, the public demanded government research into stabilization of food supplies.<ref name="Ogle2013"/> Since the 1900s, livestock production on United States farms has had to rear larger quantities of animals over a short period of time to meet new consumer demands. [[Factory farming]] originated in the late 19th century when advances in technology and science allowed for mass production of livestock. Global agriculture production doubled four times within 1820 and 1975, feeding one billion in 1800 and up to 6.5 billion in 2002.<ref>{{cite book|title=Dominion: The Power of Man, the Suffering of Animals, and the Call to Mercy|last=Scully|first=Matthew|publisher=Macmillan|year=2002|isbn=978-0-312-26147-4|ref=harv}}</ref>{{Page needed|date=August 2018}} The increase in animal densities brought the threat of disease, necessitating greater disease control. In 1950, a group of United States scientists found that adding antibiotics to [[animal feed]] increases the growth rate of livestock.<ref name="Ogle2013"/><ref>Ogle cites, "To meet this new consumer demand for animal meat, the improved health management has since introduced about seventeen classes of antimicrobial drugs is approved for use in food animals in the United States today." * {{cite journal|date=June 1950|title=They've Doubled Gains With New Drugs|journal=Successful Farming|volume=48|issue=6|page=45}} * {{cite journal|date=March 1951|title=Antibiotics Now Proved in Hog and Poultry Ratios, They're the Biggest Feeding News in 40 Years!|journal=Successful Farming|volume=49|issue=3|page=33}}</ref> [[American Cyanamid]] published research establishing the practice.<ref name="Ogle2013"/>
By 2001, this practice had grown so much that a report by the [[Union of Concerned Scientists]] found that nearly 90% of the total use of antimicrobials in the United States was for non-therapeutic purposes in agricultural production.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hogging It!: Estimates of Antimicrobial Abuse in Livestock |year=2001|publisher=Union of Concerned Scientists|url=https://www.ucsusa.org/food_and_agriculture/our-failing-food-system/industrial-agriculture/hogging-it-estimates-of.html#.Wycey1MvzEY}}</ref>
==Growth stimulation== Certain antibiotics, when given in low, sub-therapeutic doses, are known to improve [[feed conversion efficiency]] (more output, such as muscle or milk, for a given amount of feed) and may promote greater growth, most likely by affecting [[gut flora]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.merckvetmanual.com/pharmacology/growth-promotants-and-production-enhancers/antimicrobial-feed-additives|title=Antimicrobial Feed Additives|last=Reinhardt|first=Christopher|date=|work=Merck Veterinary Manual|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The drugs listed below are used to increase feed conversion ratio and weight gain. Some drugs listed below are [[ionophore]]s, which are not antibiotics and do not pose any potential risk to human health.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! colspan="5" style="background-color: #CCEEEE;" | Antibiotic Growth Promoters used in Livestock Production |- ! Drug ! Class ! Livestock |- |[[Bacitracin]] |[[Peptide]] | Beef cattle, chickens, swine, and turkeys; promotes egg production in chickens<ref name=":0" /><ref name="MerckReinhardt"/> |- |[[Bambermycin]] | |Beef cattle, chickens, swine, and turkeys.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Altered egos: antibiotic effects on food animal microbiomes|journal = Annual Review of Microbiology|date = 1 January 2014|issn = 1545-3251|pmid = 25002091|pages = 297–315|volume = 68|doi = 10.1146/annurev-micro-091213-113052|first = Heather K.|last = Allen|first2 = Thad B.|last2 = Stanton}}</ref><ref name="MerckReinhardt">{{Citation |last=Reinhardt |first=Christopher D. |year=2012 |title=[[Merck Veterinary Manual]] | chapter =Antimicrobial Feed Additives | chapter-url =http://www.merckmanuals.com/vet/pharmacology/growth_promotants_and_production_enhancers/antimicrobial_feed_additives.html |publisher=[[Merck & Co.]] and [[Merial]] |publication-place= | editor1-last =Aiello | editor1-first =Susan E.| editor2-last =Moses | editor2-first =Michael A. |page= }}</ref> |- |[[Carbadox]] | |Swine<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Laidlomycin]] | |Beef cattle<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Lasalocid]] |[[Ionophore]] |Beef cattle<ref name=":0" /><ref name="MerckReinhardt"/> |- |[[Lincomycin]] | |Chickens and swine<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Monensin]] |Ionophore |Beef cattle and sheep; promotes milk production in dairy cows<ref name=":0" /><ref name="MerckReinhardt"/> |- |[[Neomycin]]/ oxytetracyclinee | |Beef cattle, chickens, swine, and turkeys<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Penicillin]] | |Chickens, swine, and turkeys<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Roxarsone]] | |Chickens and turkeys<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Salinomycin]] |Ionophore | |- |[[Tylosin]] | |Chickens and swine<ref name=":0" /> |- |[[Virginiamycin]] |Peptide |Beef cattle, chickens, swine, turkeys<ref name=":0" /><ref name="MerckReinhardt"/> |}
== Concentrated animal feeding operations == [[Concentrated animal feeding operations]] (CAFO) refer to large, often multi-species, farming operations which lead to close animal housing quarters, rampant infections and disease, among many other malaises.<ref name=":03">{{Cite journal|last=Hribar|first=Carrie|date=2010|title=Understanding Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations and Their Impact on Communities|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nceh/ehs/docs/understanding_cafos_nalboh.pdf|journal=National Association of Local Boards of Health|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
These animals are sedentary due to the lack of space in the cramped cages. They often catch disease due to the packed rooms and ease of transmission among the manure, blood and bodily fluids. The current justification for these conditions is the belief that due to the animals not roaming, they save energy, and therefore better digest their food; this energy is reserved for growth of the animals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://amrls.cvm.msu.edu/pharmacology/antimicrobial-usage-in-animals/non-therapuetic-use-of-antimicrobials-in-animals/use-of-antibiotics-in-animals-for-growth-promotion|title=Growth Promotion — Antimicrobial Resistance Learning Site For Veterinary Students|website=amrls.cvm.msu.edu|language=en|access-date=22 June 2018}}</ref> [[File:2789694551 37beafc438 b - Grass Fed Beef - Ryan Thompson - Flickr - USDAgov.jpg|thumb|right|Organic beef comes from cattle who have not been fed antibiotics.]]
=== Manure ===
The large amounts of [[manure]] produced in cattle livestock populations are a problem for many CAFOs. Dependent on size of the operation, there can be 2,800 to 1.6 million tons of manure produced per year.<ref name="ehp.niehs.nih.gov">{{cite journal|last=Nicole|first=Wendee|date=1 June 2013|title=CAFOs and Environmental Justice: The Case of North Carolina|url=http://ehp.niehs.nih.gov/121-a182/|journal=Environmental Health Perspectives|volume=121|issue=6|pages=a182-a189|doi=10.1289/ehp.121-a182|issn=0091-6765|via=}}</ref> Annually, the livestock population in the United States produces 3 to 20 times more manure than people. However, many operations lack ultimate [[sewage treatment]].<ref name=":03" />
The manure produced from concentrated populations of animals can be diseased and have negatives impact on the environment itself. Livestock manure can be tainted by blood, pathogens such as ''E. coli'', antibiotics, growth hormones, chemical additives, etc. Some of this manure can be treated and used as [[Fertilizers|fertilizer]] by liquefying and spraying it, but larger operations often revert to storing it until it can be disposed of properly.<ref name=":03" /> Manure is also trucked off site, stored in containers, or held in holding ponds. There can be problems associated with storing manure;<ref name=":03" /> manure can have detrimental effects on the surrounding area due to leaking containers or holding ponds. This, known as ''manure leaching'', can lead to manure run-off affecting the ground or soil water by percolation or direct contamination.<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dairyherd.com/article/watch-absolute-pollution-clause|title=Watch for "Absolute Pollution" Clause|last=Lashment|first=Tiffany|date=15 November 2017|work=Dairyherd|access-date=23 June 2018|language=en}}</ref>
==== Groundwater contamination ====
When manure run-off or [[percolation]] enters a water system, the infecting agents thrive in that environment.<ref name=":22" /> Previous studies have shown private [[well water]] in Idaho found high levels of veterinary antibiotics as well as additive chemicals. The surrounding areas of concentrated animal feeding operations are at particular risk for groundwater or soil water sources of contamination.<ref name="ehp.niehs.nih.gov"/> When manure enters a water source, either underground or above ground, whatever pathogens inhabiting the manure enters the water as well. All the agents inside the manure can contaminate a water source. Pathogens survive longer in groundwater than surface water due to lower temperatures and protection from the sun and other harsher elements. Additionally, this water will not be treated until far later in the process, allowing bacterial colonies to grow.<ref name=":03" />
Groundwater is one of the larger sources of water that humans are supplied from. As of 2010, 53% of people in the United States relied on groundwater as their primary source of drinking water. Groundwater also gradually leads to surface waters, such as rivers and streams.<ref name=":03" /> Water as a contaminant is a major source of outbreak in human populations – the areas around concentrated animal feeding operations are typically at a higher risk of exposure to antibiotic-resistant bacteria strains and subsequent outbreaks.<ref name="ehp.niehs.nih.gov"/>
===== Antibiotic usage ===== The living conditions of animal feeding operations leads to a shotgun approach at targeting a sick population of livestock. Due to denser amounts of animals in smaller spaces, illness spreading and affecting a few animals can signal a precursor that more animals in an area will be infected by pathogens. In the United States, 80% of all antibiotics are given as feed additives.<ref name="Ventola 277–283">{{Cite journal|last=Ventola|first=C. Lee|date=April 2015|title=The Antibiotic Resistance Crisis|url=|journal=Pharmacy and Therapeutics|volume=40|issue=4|pages=277–283|issn=1052-1372|pmc=4378521|pmid=25859123|via=}}</ref> The antibiotics given to treat all the animals in dense area are not specific to each animal's illness and use a general approach to dosing. This leads to the antibiotics not being fully metabolized by the animals.<ref name="Marshall 718–733">{{Cite journal|last=Marshall|first=Bonnie M.|last2=Levy|first2=Stuart B.|date=October 2011|title=Food Animals and Antimicrobials: Impacts on Human Health|url=|journal=Clinical Microbiology Reviews|volume=24|issue=4|pages=718–733|doi=10.1128/CMR.00002-11|issn=0893-8512|pmc=3194830|pmid=21976606|via=}}</ref> This has been tested by levels of antibiotics still present in the manure of these animals.
===== Vectors ===== A [[Vector (epidemiology)|vector]], in this context, is an organism that transmits disease to another organism. [[Insects]] such as [[flies]] and [[mosquitoes]] have high amounts of breeding grounds and nests of eggs around manure waste, allowing rapid reproduction and fresh vectors for potential disease. Typically with dense populations of livestock, transmission of disease from one animal to another can be on account of insects, such as flies, mosquitoes or [[ticks]], spreading blood from one animal to another.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zurek|first=Ludek|last2=Ghosh|first2=Anuradha|date=June 2014|title=Insects Represent a Link between Food Animal Farms and the Urban Environment for Antibiotic Resistance Traits|url=|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|volume=80|issue=12|pages=3562–3567|doi=10.1128/AEM.00600-14|issn=0099-2240|pmc=4054130|pmid=24705326|via=}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=August 2018}} This can be particularly dangerous for sick animals spreading diseases to healthier animals, promoting general malaise in a concentrated area. Additionally, the animals can be infected from other animals' manure making contact with their food; fecal-oral transmission are one of the largest sources for pathogen transmission.<ref name=":03" /> Within concentrated animal farming operations, there is no mandatory testing of novel viruses, only reporting known illnesses to the [[World Organization for Animal Health]]. Thus, certain mutations or recombinant bacteria strains, which are more efficient in translation to human to human events, can be unnoticed.
Additionally, insect beds around manure pools or containers are a particular threat for contamination. These insects feed and reproduce in the runoff of treated manure, so they can acquire resistant strains of bacteria from blood and the manure of livestock treated with antibiotics. Since most manure holding ponds are on or near the sites of the operations, the insects are not far from livestock populations.<ref name=":03" /> These insects are also particularly dangerous because they can spread bacteria or other pathogens to humans by infecting human food. This is prevalent when treated manure is used as fertilizers of liquefied for spraying and as a result of the unsanitary handling of meat in kitchens.<ref name=":22"/>
==Use and regulation by country==
The use of drugs in food animals is regulated in nearly all countries. Historically, this has been to prevent alteration or contamination of meat, milk, eggs and other products with toxins that are harmful to humans. Treating a sick animal with drugs may lead to some of those drugs remaining in the animal when it is slaughtered or milked. Scientific experiments provide data that shows how long a drug is present in the body of an animal and what the animal's body does to the drug. Of particular concern are drugs that may be passed into milk or eggs. By the use of "drug withdrawal periods: before slaughter or the use of milk or eggs from treated animals, veterinarians and animal owners ensure that the meat, milk and eggs is free of contamination.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
===Brazil=== Brazil is the world's largest exporter of beef. The government regulates antibiotic use in the cattle production industry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Millen|first1=D. D.|last2=Pacheco|first2=R. D. L.|last3=Meyer|first3=P. M.|last4=Rodrigues|first4=P. H. M.|last5=De Beni Arrigoni|first5=M.|date=|year=2011|title=Current outlook and future perspectives of beef production in Brazil|url=|journal=Animal Frontiers|volume=1|issue=2|pages=46–52|doi=10.2527/af.2011-0017|pmc=|pmid=|via=|doi-access=free}}</ref>
===China=== China produces and consumes the most antibiotics of all countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/02/18/global-health-threat-seen-in-overuse-of-antibiotics-on-chinese-pig-farms/|title=Global Health Threat Seen in Overuse of Antibiotics on Chinese Pig Farms|last=Tatlow|first=Didi Kirsten|date=18 February 2013|work=IHT Rendezvous|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> Antibiotic use has been measured by checking the water near factory farms in China<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Wei|first1=R.|last2=Ge|first2=F.|last3=Huang|first3=S.|last4=Chen|first4=M.|last5=Wang|first5=R.|date=|year=2011|title=Occurrence of veterinary antibiotics in animal wastewater and surface water around farms in Jiangsu Province, China|url=http://qnnkxjj.cast.org.cn/uploadfile/jiangxiang/2013Jul24/1374656004765.pdf|journal=Chemosphere|volume=82|issue=10|pages=1408–1414|doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2010.11.067|pmc=|pmid=21159362|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Hu | first1 = X. | last2 = Zhou | first2 = Q. | last3 = Luo | first3 = Y. | doi = 10.1016/j.envpol.2010.05.023 | title = Occurrence and source analysis of typical veterinary antibiotics in manure, soil, vegetables and groundwater from organic vegetable bases, northern China | journal = Environmental Pollution | volume = 158 | issue = 9 | pages = 2992–2998 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20580472| pmc = }}</ref> as well as through animal feces.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhao | first1 = L. | last2 = Dong | first2 = Y. H. | last3 = Wang | first3 = H. | doi = 10.1016/j.scitotenv.2009.11.014 | title = Residues of veterinary antibiotics in manures from feedlot livestock in eight provinces of China | journal = Science of the Total Environment | volume = 408 | issue = 5 | pages = 1069–1075 | year = 2010 | pmid = 19954821| pmc = }}</ref> It was calculated that 38.5 million kg (or 84.9 million lbs) of antibiotics were used in China's swine and poultry production in 2012.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Krishnasamy|first1=Vikram|last2=Otte|first2=Joachim|last3=Silbergeld|first3=Ellen|date=28 April 2015|title=Antimicrobial use in Chinese swine and broiler poultry production|url=|journal=Antimicrobial Resistance and Infection Control|volume=4|issue=1|pages=17|doi=10.1186/s13756-015-0050-y|issn=2047-2994|ref=harv|via=|doi-access=free}}</ref> The abuse of antibiotics caused severe pollution of soil and surface water in Northern China.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mu|first1=Quanhua|last2=Li|first2=Jin|last3=Sun|first3=Yingxue|last4=Mao|first4=Daqing|last5=Wang|first5=Qing|last6=Yi|first6=Luo|title=Occurrence of sulfonamide-, tetracycline-, plasmid-mediated quinolone- and macrolide-resistance genes in livestock feedlots in Northern China|journal=Springer|date=5 December 2014|volume=22|issue=6932-6940|doi=10.1007/s11356-014-3905-5}}</ref>
In 2012, [[U.S. News & World Report]] described the Chinese government's regulation of antibiotics in livestock production as "weak".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://health.usnews.com/health-news/news/articles/2013/02/11/chinas-overuse-of-antibiotics-in-livestock-may-threaten-human-health |title=China's Overuse of Antibiotics in Livestock May Threaten Human Health |first=Maureen |last=Salamon |work=health.usnews.com |date=11 February 2013 |accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>
===European Union===
In 1999, the European Union (EU) implemented an antibiotic resistance monitoring program and a plan to phase out antibiotic use for the purposes of growth promotion by 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-05-1687_en.htm|last=European Union|first=|date=2005|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 December 2005}}</ref> The European Union banned the use of antibiotics as growth agents starting on 1 January 2006 with Regulation (EC) No 1831/2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.europa.eu/eli/reg/2003/1831/oj|title=EUR-Lex - 32003R1831 - EN - EUR-Lex|website=data.europa.eu}}</ref> In [[Germany]], 1,734 tons of antimicrobial agents were used for animals in 2011 compared with 800 tons for humans.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} [[Sweden]] banned their use in 1986 and [[Denmark]] started cutting down drastically in 1994, now using 60% less.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/danish-pig-farmers-reduce-antibiotics-to-prevent-drug-resistance-a-933344.html|title=Cutting Antibiotics : Denmark Leads Way in Healthier Pig Farming|last=Koch|first=Julia|date=13 November 2013|work=Spiegel Online|access-date=22 May 2014}}</ref> In [[the Netherlands]], the use of antibiotics to treat diseases increased after the ban on its use for growth purposes in 2006.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cogliani|first1=Carol|last2=Goossens|first2=Herman|last3=Greko|first3=Christina|date=1 January 2011|title=Restricting Antimicrobial Use in Food Animals: Lessons from Europe|journal=Microbe Magazine|volume=6|issue=6|pages=274–279|doi=10.1128/microbe.6.274.1|issn=1558-7452|ref=harv}}</ref>
In 2011, the European Parliament voted for a non-binding resolution that called for the end of pre-emptive use of antibiotics in livestock.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//TEXT+IM-PRESS+20111026IPR30419+0+DOC+XML+V0//EN|title=Parliament demands smarter use of antibiotics|website=www.europarl.europa.eu}}</ref>
A revised regulation on veterinary medicinal products, proposed in procedure 2014/0257/COD, would limit the use of antibiotics in prophylaxis and metaphylaxis. An agreement on the regulation between the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament was confirmed on 13 June 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/procedure/EN/2014_257|title=EUR-Lex - 2014_257 - EN - EUR-Lex|website=eur-lex.europa.eu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2018/06/13/veterinary-medicines-new-eu-rules-to-enhance-availability-and-fight-against-antimicrobial-resistance/|title=Veterinary medicines: new EU rules to enhance availability and fight against antimicrobial resistance - Consilium|website=www.consilium.europa.eu}}</ref>
===India=== In 2011 the Indian government proposed a "National policy for containment of antimicrobial resistance".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.indianexpress.com/news/govt-wants-to-limit-use-of-antibiotics-in-animals/775330/ |title=Govt wants to limit use of antibiotics in animals – Indian Express |first=Teena |last=Thacker |work=indianexpress.com |date=13 April 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> Other policies set schedules for requiring that food producing animals not be given antibiotics for a certain amount of time before their food goes to market.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-25/science/30440181_1_antibiotic-resistance-poultry-products-livestock |title=New norm to curb antibiotic resistance – Times of India |first=Kounteya |last=Sinha |work=indiatimes.com |date=25 November 2011 |accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-04-06/india/31300016_1_antibiotics-seafood-and-poultry-products-staphylococcus |title=In a first, antibiotics bar on food-producing animals – Times of India |first=Kounteya |last=Sinha |work=indiatimes.com |date=6 April 2012 |accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> A study released by Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) on 30 July 2014 found antibiotic residues in chicken. This study claims that Indians are developing resistance to antibiotics – and hence falling prey to a host of otherwise curable ailments. Some of this resistance might be due to large-scale unregulated use of antibiotics in the poultry industry. CSE finds that India has not set any limits for antibiotic residues in chicken and says that India will have to implement a comprehensive set of regulations including banning of antibiotic use as growth promoters in the poultry industry. Not doing this will put lives of people at risk.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cseindia.org/node/5487/ |title=Centre For Science and Environment (CSE)|work=Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) |date=30 July 2014|accessdate=30 July 2014}}</ref>
===New Zealand=== In 1999 the New Zealand government issued a statement that they would not then ban the use of antibiotics in livestock production.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=1071 |title=NZ holds off ban on animal antibiotics – National – NZ Herald News |first= |last=staff |work=nzherald.co.nz |date=7 January 1999 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref> In 2007 [[ABC Online]] reported on antibiotic use in chicken production in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/scienceshow/antibiotics-and-intensive-chicken-farming-in-new/3222458#transcript |title=Antibiotics and intensive chicken farming in New Zealand – The Science Show |first1=Robyn |last1=Williams |first2=Greg |last2=Cook |work=abc.net.au |date=11 August 2007 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref>
===South Korea=== In 1998 some researchers reported use in livestock production was a factor in the high prevalence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria in Korea.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kim |first1=Woo Joo |last2=Park |first2=Seung Chull |title=bacterial Resistance to Antimicrobial Agents: An Overview from Korea |journal=[[Yonsei Medical Journal]] |year=1998 |volume=39 |issue=6 |pages=488–494 |url=http://www.eymj.org/Synapse/Data/PDFData/0069YMJ/ymj-39-488.pdf|accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref> In 2007 ''[[The Korea Times]]'' noted that Korea has relatively high usage of antibiotics in livestock production.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/2010/06/180_5376.html |title=Antibiotics in Livestock Harm Human Beings |first=Yoon |last=Won-sup |work=[[The Korea Times]] |date=25 June 2007 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref> In 2011, the Korean government banned the use of antibiotics as growth promoters in livestock.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2011/06/south-korea-bans-antibiotics-in-animal-feed/#.Uh99Nm2KLm0 |title=South Korea Bans Antibiotics in Animal Feed |first=Dan |last=Flynn |work=foodsafetynews.com |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref>
===United States=== In 1970 the FDA started recommending that antibiotic use in livestock be limited but set no actual regulations governing this recommendation.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> By 2001, the [[Union of Concerned Scientists]] estimated that greater than 70% of the antibiotics used in the U.S. are given to food animals (for example, chickens, pigs, and cattle), in the absence of disease.<ref name="TheRealNews-2014-05-18">{{cite web|url=http://therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=74&jumival=11872|title=Why Are Antibiotics Becoming Useless All Over the World?|author=Martin Khor|authorlink=Martin Khor|date=18 May 2014|publisher=''[[The Real News]]''|accessdate=18 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucsusa.org/food_and_agriculture/our-failing-food-system/industrial-agriculture/hogging-it-estimates-of.html#.Wycey1MvzEY|title=Executive summary from the UCS report "Hogging It: Estimates of Antimicrobial Abuse in Livestock"|date=January 2001|publisher=Union of Concerned Scientists|ref=harv}}</ref>
In 2004 the [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) heavily critiqued the FDA for not collecting enough information and data on antibiotic use in factory farms. From this, the GAO concluded that the FDA does not have enough information to create effective policy changes regarding antibiotic use. In response, the FDA insisted that more research was being conducted and voluntary efforts within the industry would solve the problem of antibiotic resistance.<ref>GAO. 2011: Antibiotic Resistance: Agencies Have Made Limited Progress Addressing Antibiotic Use in Animals. GAO-11-801.</ref>
Few policies exist that limit antibiotic use on factory farms, and some proposed legislation in the US has failed to be adopted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grist.org/article/food-we-need-legislation-to-fix-food-safety-and-our-oversight-agencies-to/|title=UPDATED: With the food safety bill dead, time for the FDA/USDA to grow some backbone|last=Philpott|first=Tom|date=17 September 2010|work=''[[Grist (magazine)|Grist]]''|accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> In 2007, two federal bills (S. 549<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s110-549|title=US Senate Bill S. 549: Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act of 2007|ref=harv}}</ref> and H.R. 962<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h110-962|title=Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act of 2007|ref=harv}}</ref>) aimed to phase out nontherapeutic antibiotics in U.S. food animal production. The Senate bill, introduced by Sen [[Ted Kennedy]], died. The House bill, introduced by Rep. [[Louise Slaughter]], died after being referred to Committee. The U.S. Animal Drug User Fee Act was passed by Congress in 2008, requiring that drug manufacturers report all sales of antibiotics into the food animal production industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/laura-rogers/animal-antibiotics_b_2375953.html|title=Laura Rogers: A New Year's Resolution: Put Animals on an Antibiotics Diet|last=Rogers|first=Laura|date=28 December 2012|work=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/david-wallinga-md/animal-antibiotic-use_b_2654385.html|title=David Wallinga, M.D.: Animal Antibiotic Use Continues Upwards, FDA Keeps Blinders on|last=Wallinga|first=David|date=12 February 2013|work=huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref>
By 2011, a total of {{Convert|13.6|e6kg|e6lb|abbr=unit}} of antimicrobials were sold for use in food-producing animals in the United States,<ref name="FDA2013">{{Cite report|url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/ForIndustry/UserFees/AnimalDrugUserFeeActADUFA/UCM440584.pdf|title=Summary Report on Antimicrobials Sold or Distributed for Use in Food-Producing Animals|last=|first=|date=2013|publisher=FDA|issue=|doi=|volume=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> which represented 80% of all antibiotics sold or distributed in the United States.<ref name="FDA 2012, Drug Use Review, Table 1">{{Cite report|url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/drugs/drugsafety/informationbydrugclass/ucm319435.pdf|title=Drug Use Review|last=|first=|date=2012|publisher=FDA|issue=|doi=|volume=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Of the antibiotics given to animals from 2009 through 2013, just above 60% distributed for food animal use are "medically-important" drugs that are also used in humans.<ref name="FDA2013" /> The rest were drug classes like [[ionophores]], which are not used in human medicine.<ref name="Guidance for Industry: Evaluating the Safety of Antimicrobial New Animal Drugs with Regard to Their Microbiological Effects on Bacteria of Human Health Concern">{{Cite document|url=https://www.fda.gov/downloads/AnimalVeterinary/GuidanceComplianceEnforcement/GuidanceforIndustry/ucm052519.pdf|title=Evaluating the Safety of Antimicrobial New Animal Drugs with Regard to Their Microbiological Effects on Bacteria of Human Health Concern|last=|first=|date=2003|journal=Guidance for Industry|pages=|via=|publisher=FDA Center for Veterinary Medicine|issue=#152|volume=}}</ref>
In March 2012, the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]], ruling in an action brought by the [[Natural Resources Defense Council]] and others, ordered the FDA to revoke approvals for the use of antibiotics in livestock that violated FDA regulations.<ref name="MPFDA">{{cite news |title=FDA Told to Move on Antibiotic Use in Livestock|url=http://www.medpagetoday.com/PublicHealthPolicy/FDAGeneral/31792|accessdate=24 March 2012|newspaper=MedPage Today|date=23 March 2012|author=John Gever}}</ref> On 11 April 2012 the FDA announced a voluntary program to phase out unsupervised use of drugs as feed additives and convert approved over-the-counter uses for antibiotics to prescription use only, requiring veterinarian supervision of their use and a prescription.<ref name="NYTPrescription">{{cite news |title=U.S. Tightens Rules on Antibiotics Use for Livestock|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/12/us/antibiotics-for-livestock-will-require-prescription-fda-says.html|accessdate=12 April 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 April 2012|author=Gardiner Harris}}</ref><ref name="FDAFAQ">{{cite web |title=FDA's Strategy on Antimicrobial Resistance — Questions and Answers|url=http://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/GuidanceComplianceEnforcement/GuidanceforIndustry/ucm216939.htm|publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration|accessdate=12 April 2012|date=11 April 2012|quote="Judicious use" is using an antimicrobial drug appropriately and only when necessary; Based on a thorough review of the available scientific information, FDA recommends that use of medically important antimicrobial drugs in food-producing animals be limited to situations where the use of these drugs is necessary for ensuring animal health, and their use includes veterinary oversight or consultation. FDA believes that using medically important antimicrobial drugs to increase production in food-producing animals is not a judicious use.}}</ref> In December 2013, the FDA announced the commencement of these steps to phase out the use of antibiotics for the purposes of promoting livestock growth.<ref name="TheRealNews-2014-05-18" /><ref>{{cite web |last=Tavernise|first=Sabrina|title=F.D.A. to Phase Out Use of Some Antibiotics in Animals Raised for Meat|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/12/health/fda-to-phase-out-use-of-some-antibiotics-in-animals-raised-for-meat.html|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref>
Numerous state senators and members of congress showed support for the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act of 2013 and Preventing Antibiotic Resistance Act of 2015. These acts proposed amendments be made to the [[Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act|Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act]] which would limit and preserve the use of antibiotics for medically necessary situations. Both of these bills died in Congress in 2015.<ref>Govtrack.us https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/113/hr1150</ref>
In 2015, the FDA approved a new Veterinary Feed Directive (VFD), which is an updated guideline that give instructions to pharmaceutical companies, veterinarians, and producers about how to administer necessary drugs through the animal's feed and water.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/AnimalVeterinary/GuidanceComplianceEnforcement/GuidanceforIndustry/ucm216939.htm|title=FDA's Strategy on Antimicrobial Resistance - Questions and Answers|last=Center for Veterinary Medicine|first=|date=|website=Guidance for Industry|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}}</ref> The FDA has asked drug companies to voluntarily edit its labels to exclude growth promotion as an indication for antibiotic usage. FDA regulations on off-label use prohibit using a drug off-label for non-therapeutic purposes, which would make using the re-labeled drug for growth enhancement illegal. Some drugs are also being re-classified from OTC to VFD; VFD drugs require a veterinarian's authorization before it can be delivered in feed. The new guidelines took effect on 1 January 2017.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://ahdc.vet.cornell.edu/programs/NYSCHAP/nysvfrp/vfd.cfm#AffectedVFD|title=VFD – Veterinary Feed Directive|last=Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=":3" />
{{Quote|text=The key aspect of FDA’s strategy is the request that animal drug sponsors (those who own the right to market the product) voluntarily work with FDA to revise the approved use conditions for their medically important antimicrobial drug products to remove production uses (such as growth enhancement or feed efficiency), and bring the remaining therapeutic uses under veterinary oversight. Once manufacturers voluntarily make these changes, products can no longer be used for production purposes and therapeutic use of these products would require veterinary oversight.<ref name=":3" />|sign=|source=}}
==== Private entities ==== Some [[grocery stores]] have policies about voluntarily not selling meat produced by using antibiotics to stimulate growth. In response to consumer concerns about the [[use of antibiotics in poultry]], [[Perdue Farms|Perdue]] removed all human antibiotics from its feed in 2007 and launched the Harvestland brand, under which it sold products that met the requirements for an "antibiotic-free" label. By 2014, Perdue had also phased out ionophores from its hatchery and began using the "antibiotic free" labels on its Harvestland, Simply Smart, and Perfect Portions products.<ref name="Stephanie Strom">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/01/business/perdue-and-the-race-to-end-antibiotic-use-in-chickens.html|title=Perdue Sharply Cuts Antibiotic Use in Chickens and Jabs at Its Rivals|author=Stephanie Strom|date=31 July 2015|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> By 2015, 52% of the company's chickens were raised without the use of any type of antibiotics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://perduefarms.com/News_Room/Statements_and_Comments/details.asp?id=545&title=Antibiotics%20Position%20Statement|title=Antibiotics Position Statement|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2012 in the United States advocacy organization [[Consumers Union]] organized a petition asking the store [[Trader Joe's]] to discontinue the sale of meat produced with antibiotics.<ref>{{cite web|title=Meat Without Drugs|url=http://www.meatwithoutdrugs.org|publisher=[[Consumers Union]]|accessdate=27 August 2013}}, which is described in the following works
*{{cite book|last=Gore|first=Al|title=[[The Future : Six Drivers of Global Change]]|year=2013|publisher=[[Random House]]|location=New York|isbn=9780812992946|pages=227 and citation on 475|edition=First edition.|authorlink=Al Gore|chapter=The Reinvention of Life and Death: Antibiotics before Swine}} *{{cite journal|last=Hurd|first=Scott|title=Commentary: 'Meat without Drugs' could be inhumane|journal=Bovine Veterinarian|date=26 June 2012|url=http://www.bovinevetonline.com/news/industry/Commentary-Meat-without-Drugs-could-be-inhumane-160409875.html|accessdate=27 August 2013|quote=All peer-reviewed scientific risk assessments have demonstrated a negligible risk of human health harm due to livestock antibiotic use.}} *{{cite journal|last=Greenaway|first=Twilight|title=Your meat on drugs: Will grocery stores cut out antibiotics?|journal=[[Grist (magazine)|Grist]]|date=20 June 2012|url=http://grist.org/factory-farms/your-meat-on-drugs-can-grocery-stores-be-convinced-to-cut-out-antibiotics/|accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref>
==Antibiotic resistance== There has been increased concern about the use of anti-microbials in animals (including pets, livestock, and companion animals) contributing to the rise in [[antibiotic resistance|antibiotic-resistant infections]] in humans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ucsusa.org/food_and_agriculture/our-failing-food-system/industrial-agriculture/prescription-for-trouble.html|title=Prescription for Trouble: Using Antibiotics to Fatten Livestock|last=Union of Concerned Scientists|first=|date=11 August 2009|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=29 November 2015}}</ref> Around 70% of all antibiotics administered are used for livestock. Some drugs are used in livestock feed to prevent illnesses and or increase growth rates, but others are used as treatment for illnesses. The use of antibiotics in livestock can bring antibiotic-resistant bacteria to humans via consumption of meat and ingestion through airborne bacteria. Manure from food-producing animals can also contain antibiotic-resistant bacteria and is sometimes stored in lagoons. This waste is often sprayed as fertilizer and can thus contaminate crops and water with the bacteria.<ref>{{Cite report|url=https://www.foodandwaterwatch.org/sites/default/files/Antibiotic%20Resistance%20101%20Report%20March%202015.pdf|title=Antibiotic Resistance 101: How How Antibiotic Misuse on Factory Farms Can Make You Sick|last=Food & Water Watch|first=|date=2015|issue=|doi=|volume=|pages=1–17|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
The World Health Organization has published a list, "Critically Important Antimicrobials for Human Medicine", with the intent that it be used "as a reference to help formulate and prioritize risk assessment and risk management strategies for containing antimicrobial resistance due to human and non-human antimicrobial use."<ref>{{Cite report|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/77376/9789241504485_eng.pdf|title=Critically Important Antimicrobials for Human Medicine|last=World Health Organization|first=|date=2011|issue=|doi=|volume=|pmid=|access-date=11 April 2016}}</ref>
=== Effects in humans ===
The effects of antibiotic usage in livestock transferring to humans has been well documented for over 40 years.<ref name="Ventola 277–283"/> It was first documented in 1976, where a study followed a novel antibiotic being used in livestock. The bacteria in animals and workers were regularly followed to record translational effects. The findings revealed that within 2 weeks, the bacteria found in the guts of animals fed antibiotics were resistant to the new antibiotic.<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Economou|first=Vangelis|last2=Gousia|first2=Panagiota|date=1 April 2015|title=Agriculture and food animals as a source of antimicrobial-resistant bacteria|journal=Infection and Drug Resistance|volume=8|pages=49–61|doi=10.2147/IDR.S55778|issn=1178-6973|pmc=4388096|pmid=25878509}}</ref> Additionally, the resistant bacteria had spread to farm's laborers within 6 months. The bacteria in the stool of the laborers were tested and contained more than 80% resistance to the initial antibiotic given to the livestock.<ref name="Marshall 718–733"/> Since the primary study, there have been many well-documented events showing that antibiotic usage in livestock results in direct influence of antibiotic resistance in humans.
Major bacterial infections in humans can be traced back to livestock. The family [[Enterobacteriaceae]] includes many opportunistic bacteria, including ''[[E. coli]]'',<ref name=":32"/> which are commonly found in livestock. Other bacteria include ''[[Klebsiella]]'' and ''[[Staphylococcus aureus]]''. They cause infections in the [[Urinary tract infection|urinary tract]], digestive system, [[Skin infection|skin]], and [[Bloodstream infection|bloodstream]], and account for a significant portion of antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections.<ref name=":32"/>
===Advocates for restricting antibiotic use=== The practice of using antibiotics for growth stimulation is problematic for these reasons:<ref name="Silbergeld">{{Cite journal|last1=Silbergeld|first1=E. K.|last2=Graham|first2=J.|last3=Price|first3=L. B.|date=|year=2008|title=Industrial Food Animal Production, Antimicrobial Resistance, and Human Health|url=|journal=Annual Review of Public Health|volume=29|pages=151–169|doi=10.1146/annurev.publhealth.29.020907.090904|pmc=|pmid=18348709|via=|doi-access=free}}</ref>
*It is the largest use of antimicrobials worldwide *Subtherapeutic use of antibiotics results in bacterial resistance *Every important class of antibiotics are being used in this way, making every class less effective *The bacteria being changed harm humans
[[Donald Kennedy]], former director of the FDA, has said "There's no question that routinely administering non-therapeutic doses of antibiotics to food animals contributes to antibiotic resistance."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/sep/19/scientists-antibiotics-animal-agriculture|title=Scientists: overuse of antibiotics in animal agriculture endangers humans|last=McVeigh|first=Karen|date=19 September 2012|work=The Guardian|access-date=23 August 2013|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> [[David Aaron Kessler]], another former director, stated, "We have more than enough scientific evidence to justify curbing the rampant use of antibiotics for livestock, yet the food and drug industries are not only fighting proposed legislation to reduce these practices, they also oppose collecting the data."<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/28/opinion/antibiotics-and-the-meat-we-eat.html?_r=0 |title=Antibiotics and the Meat We Eat |first=David Aaron |last=Kessler |authorlink=David Aaron Kessler |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=27 March 2013 |publisher=[[New York Times Company|NYTC]] |location=New York City |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref>
In 2013, the US [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) published a white paper discussing antibiotic resistance threats in the US and calling for "improved use of antibiotics" among other measures to contain the threat to human health. The CDC asked leaders in agriculture, healthcare, and other disciplines to work together to combat the issue of increasing antibiotic resistance.<ref name="cdc.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/drugresistance/pdf/ar-threats-2013-508.pdf|title=Antibiotic Resistance Threats in the United States|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref>
Some scientists have said that "all therapeutic antimicrobial agents should be available only by prescription for human and veterinary use."<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gilchrist | first1 = M. J. | last2 = Greko | first2 = C. | last3 = Wallinga | first3 = D. B. | last4 = Beran | first4 = G. W. | last5 = Riley | first5 = D. G. | last6 = Thorne | first6 = P. S. | doi = 10.1289/ehp.8837 | title = The Potential Role of Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations in Infectious Disease Epidemics and Antibiotic Resistance | journal = Environmental Health Perspectives | volume = 115 | issue = 2 | pages = 313–316 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17384785| pmc =1817683 }}</ref>
[[The Pew Charitable Trusts]] have stated that "hundreds of scientific studies conducted over four decades demonstrate that feeding low doses of antibiotics to livestock breeds antibiotic-resistant superbugs that can infect people. The FDA, the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention all testified before Congress that there is a definitive link between the routine, non-therapeutic use of antibiotics in food animal production and the challenge of antibiotic resistance in humans."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/news_room_detail.aspx?id=85899424573|title=Pew Comments on Proposed Antibiotics Legislation|author=The Pew Charitable Trusts|first=|authorlink=The Pew Charitable Trusts|date=15 October 2012|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=26 August 2013}}</ref>
[[HSBC]] produced a report in October 2018 warning that the use of antibiotics in meat production could have “devastating” consequences for humans. It noted that many dairy and meat producers in Asia and the Americas had an economic incentive to continue high usage of antibiotics, particularly in crowded or unsanitary living conditions.<ref>{{cite news |title=One of the world's largest banks has issued an alarming warning about antibiotic resistance — with big consequences for humanity |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/hsbc-says-meat-production-creates-devastating-antibiotic-resistance-2018-10 |accessdate=13 November 2018 |publisher=Business Insider UK |date=10 October 2018}}</ref>
===Moderate positions=== The [[World Organisation for Animal Health]] has acknowledged the need to protect antibiotics but argued against a total ban on antibiotic use in animal production.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/11/us-antibiotics-livestock-idUSTRE80A1JF20120111 |title=Antibiotics for livestock vital to feed world: OIE | Reuters |first=Sybille |last=de La Hamaide |work=reuters.com |date=11 January 2012 |accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>

animals to antibiotic resistance in humans, as the U.S. pork industry has continually pointed out, but there isn't even adequate data to conduct a study."<ref> *{{cite web |url= ===Effects of restricting antibiotic use=== When government regulation restricts use of antibiotics, the negative economic impact is not often considered.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Phillips|first1=I.|last2=Casewell|first2=M.|last3=Cox|first3=T.|last4=De Groot|first4=B.|last5=Friis|first5=C.|last6=Jones|first6=R.|last7=Nightingale|first7=C.|last8=Preston|first8=R.|last9=Waddell|first9=J.|date=|year=2003|title=Does the use of antibiotics in food animals pose a risk to human health? A critical review of published data|url=|journal=Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy|volume=53|issue=1|pages=28–52|doi=10.1093/jac/dkg483|pmc=|pmid=14657094|via=|doi-access=free}}</ref>
Regulation of antibiotics in livestock production would affect the business models of corporations such as [[Tyson Foods]], [[Cargill]], and [[Hormel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/11/us-fda-antibiotics-idUSBRE83A0Y420120411|title=U.S. seeks voluntary antibiotic limits in livestock|last=Yukhananov|first=Anna|date=11 April 2012|work=Reuters|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>
===Difficulties with determining relevant facts=== It is difficult to set up a comprehensive surveillance system for measuring rates of change in antibiotic resistance.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Bax|first1=R.|last2=Bywater|first2=R.|last3=Cornaglia|first3=G.|last4=Goossens|first4=H.|last5=Hunter|first5=P.|last6=Isham|first6=V.|last7=Jarlier|first7=V.|last8=Jones|first8=R.|last9=Phillips|first9=I.|date=|year=2001|title=Surveillance of antimicrobial resistance-what, how and whither?|url=|journal=Clinical Microbiology and Infection|volume=7|issue=6|pages=316–325|doi=10.1046/j.1198-743x.2001.00239.x|pmc=|pmid=11442565|via=|doi-access=free|last10=Sahm|first10=D.|last11=Senn|first11=S.|last12=Struelens|first12=M.|last13=Taylor|first13=D.|last14=White|first14=A.}}</ref> The US [[Government Accountability Office]] published a report in 2011 stating that government and commercial agencies had not been collecting sufficient data to make a decision about best practices.<ref>{{Cite report|url=https://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-11-801|title=Agencies Have Made Limited Progress Addressing Antibiotic Use in Animals|last=U.S. Government Accountability Office|first=|date=7 September 2011|issue=GAO-11-801|doi=|volume=|pmid=|author-link=U.S. Government Accountability Office|access-date=27 August 2013}}</ref>
Currently,{{As of?|date=August 2018}} there is no regulatory agency in the United States that systematically collects detailed data on antibiotic use in humans and animals. It is not clear which antibiotics are prescribed for which purpose and at what time. Furthermore, the world has no surveillance infrastructure to monitor emerging antibiotic resistance threats. Because of these issues, it is difficult to quantify antibiotic resistance, to regulate antibiotic prescribing practices, and to detect and respond to rising threats.<ref name="cdc.gov"/>
===Specific resistance that has been identified=== At this time,{{When|date=August 2018}} the most well-documented impact on humans is foodborne [[gastrointestinal illness]]. In most cases, these illnesses are mild and do not require antibiotics; though if the infectious bacteria is drug-resistant, they have increased virulence (ability to cause disease) and lead to prolonged illness. Furthermore, in approximately 10% of cases, the disease becomes severe, requiring more advanced treatments. These treatments can take the form of [[intravenous antibiotics]], supportive care for blood infections, and hospital stays, leading to higher costs and greater [[morbidity]], with a trend toward higher [[Mortality rate|mortality]].<ref name="cdc.gov"/><ref name="Molbak K 2005">{{cite journal|last=Mølbak|first=Kåre|date=1 December 2005|title=Human health consequences of antimicrobial drug-resistant Salmonella and other foodborne pathogens|url=https://watermark.silverchair.com/41-11-1613.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAAaEwggGdBgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggGOMIIBigIBADCCAYMGCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMC5CcxYVEEcpIfQQwAgEQgIIBVFZIhxln25cPgixDMekED8VU0rvjgFuF58TiE8hh1h8cByCTThMJQBbFwgZZKXaRDP5tmE0lxuPxtbhe_rv30AfRWQCQ1_Fi_nxcytW23OdoFkSdgbtDSf1rVQGR-iR3wdKrmzP5MLqXUQzgFmL7uK5s63yxEmpVsLoPE33jlTu_eJBIjeJTSwLwbtb11yy1rdECA9mhOPRU2RY4GNit2Zk2dsxz53QoMB5htdm3aZnyTLrPdPU_DyikmzelbTNmDuM0mhxmD-4o2gD3Z_qp7HtpMCJCJBSxj0T8m8eLePYXDeochIZLpFvdIDRdCf3WjPUEFg9SE3-RKGgiGYFAPMaM58u9b7B88hO4JxEwXNCXF_ea-Gw-aLmmc1Ny8G_-qpw_DUWQRzKJ7x69rLZaV29gjTG88rSadRBf6XYWcYBxr3a-CQuSP3_fSEsje2FRBwfPxxo|journal=Clinical first8=Andreas Munk | last9=Wegener | first9=Henrik C. | title=An Outbreak of Multidrug-Resistant, Quinolone-Resistant Salmonella enterica Serotype Typhimurium DT104 | journal=New England Journal of Medicine | date=4 November 1999 | pages=1420–1425 | pmid=10547404 | doi=10.1056/NEJM199911043411902 | issn=0028-4793 | volume=341 | issue=19 | doi-access=free}}</ref><ref name="Shea K.M. 2003">{{cite Health?|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/112/Supplement_1/253|journal=Pediatrics|volume=112|issue=Supplement 1|pages=253–258|issn=0031-4005|pmid=12837918|via=|doi-access=}}</ref>
Over the past 20 years, the most common drug-resistant foodborne bacteria in industrialized countries have been non-typhoidal ''[[Salmonella]]'' and ''[[Campylobacter]]''. Research has consistently shown the main contributing factors are bacteria sourced in livestock.<ref name="Molbak K 2005"/> A 1998 outbreak of multidrug-resistant ''Salmonella'' in Denmark linked back to two Danish swine herds.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Coupled with the discovery of this link, there have been improved monitoring systems that have helped to quantify the impact. In the United States, it is estimated that there are approximately 400,000 cases and over 35,000 hospitalizations per year attributable to increasing resistant strains of ''Salmonella'' and ''Campylobacter''. In terms of financial impact in the US, the treatment of non-typhoidal ''Salmonella'' infections alone is now estimated to cost $365 million per year.<ref name="cdc.gov"/><ref name="NARMS 2013">{{Cite report|url=https://www.cdc.gov/narms/pdf/2013-annual-report-narms-508c.pdf|title=Human Isolates Final Report|last=Center for Disease Control and Prevention|first=|date=2013|issue=|doi=|volume=|pmid=|access-date=|work=National Antibiotic Resistance Monitoring System: Enteric Bacteria}}</ref> In light of this, in its inaugural 2013 report on antibiotic resistance threats in the United States, the CDC identified resistant non-typhoidal ''Salmonella'' and ''Campylobacter'' as "serious threats" and called for improved surveillance and intervention in food production moving forward.<ref name="cdc.gov"/>
There are other bacteria as well, where research is evolving and revealing that bacterial resistance acquired through use in livestock may be contributing to disease in humans. Examples of these include Enterococcus (including [[E. coli 0157 H7|''E. coli'' 0157]]) and ''Staphylococcus aureus''. For foodborne illness from ''E. coli'', which is still not typically treated with antibiotics because of associated risk of [[renal failure]], increasing rates of antibiotic-resistant infections have been correlated with increasing virulence of the bacteria.<ref name="NARMS 2013"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Swartz|first=Morton N.|date=1 June 2002|title=Human Diseases Caused by Foodborne Pathogens of Animal Origin|journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases|volume=34|issue=Supplement_3|pages=S111-S122|doi=10.1086/340248|issn=1058-4838|ref=harv|doi-access=free}}</ref> In the case of Enterococcus and ''S. aureus'', resistant forms of both of these bacteria have resulted in greatly increasing morbidity and mortality in the US.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> At this point, there have been studies, though a limited number, that definitively link antibiotic use in food production to these resistance patterns in humans and further research will help to further characterize this relationship.<ref name="Shea K.M. 2003"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Bortolaia V|first=|displayauthors=etal|date=Feb 2016|title=Human health risks associated with antimicrobial-resistant enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus on poultry meat|url=|journal=Clinical Microbiology and Infection|volume=22|issue=2|pages=130–40|doi=10.1016/j.cmi.2015.12.003|via=|doi-access=free}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Wegener H | year = 2003 | title = Antibiotics in animal feed and their role in resistance development | url = | journal = Current Opinion in Microbiology | volume = 6 | issue = | pages = 439–445 | doi=10.1016/j.mib.2003.09.009}}</ref>[[File:TangledwebSaureus.png|thumb|The origins of antibiotic-resistant ''Staphylococcus aureus'' (CAFO: concentrated animal feeding operations)|403x403px]]
===Mechanisms for transfer to humans=== The amounts given are termed "sub-therapeutic", i.e., insufficient to combat disease. Despite no diagnosis of disease, the administration of these drugs result in decreased mortality and morbidity and increased growth in the animals so treated. It is theorized that sub-therapeutic dosages kills some, but not all, of the bacterial organisms in the animal – likely leaving those that are naturally antibiotic-resistant.<ref>{{cite book |first=Henrik C. |last=Wegener |chapter=A15 Antibiotic Resistance—Linking Human and Animal Health |chapterurl=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK114485/ |id=NBK114485 |editor=Choffnes, E.R.|editor2=Relman, D.A.|editor3=Olsen, L.|editor4=Hutton, R.|editor5=Mack, A. |title=Antibiotic Resistance — Linking Human And Animal Health: Improving Food Safety Through a One Health Approach Workshop Summary |publisher=National Academies Press |location=Washington DC |year=2012 |isbn=978-0-309-25937-8 |pages= |doi=10.17226/13423}}</ref> The actual mechanism by which sub-therapeutic antibiotic feed additives serve as growth promoters is thus unclear. Some people have speculated that animals and fowl may have sub-clinical infections, which would be cured by low levels of antibiotics in feed, thereby allowing the creatures to thrive.
Humans can be exposed to antibiotic-resistant bacteria by ingesting them through the food supply. Dairy products, ground beef, and poultry are the most common foods harboring these pathogens.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cspinet.org/sites/default/files/attachment/outbreaks_antibiotic_resistance_in_foodborne_pathogens_2013.pdf|title=Antibiotic Resistance in Foodborne Pathogens|last1=DeWaal|first1=J.D.|last2=Grooters|first2=Susan Vaughn|date=May 2013|work=Center for Science in the Public Interest|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> There is evidence that a large proportion of resistant ''[[Escherichia coli|E. coli]]'' isolates causing blood stream infections in people are from livestock produced as food.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Vieira|first1=A. R.|last2=Collignon|first2=P.|last3=Aarestrup|first3=F. M.|last4=McEwen|first4=S. A.|last5=Hendriksen|first5=R. S.|last6=Hald|first6=T.|last7=Wegener|first7=H. C.|date=|year=2011|title=Association Between Antimicrobial Resistance inEscherichia coliIsolates from Food Animals and Blood Stream Isolates from Humans in Europe: An Ecological Study|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Rene_Hendriksen/publication/51611642_Association_Between_Antimicrobial_Resistance_in_Escherichia_coli_Isolates_from_Food_Animals_and_Blood_Stream_Isolates_from_Humans_in_Europe_An_Ecological_Study/links/55a9efc508aea3d08680491e/Association-Between-Antimicrobial-Resistance-in-Escherichia-coli-Isolates-from-Food-Animals-and-Blood-Stream-Isolates-from-Humans-in-Europe-An-Ecological-Study.pdf|journal=Foodborne Pathogens and Disease|volume=8|issue=12|pages=1295–1301|doi=10.1089/fpd.2011.0950|pmc=|pmid=21883007|via=}}</ref>
When manure from antibiotic-fed swine is used as fertilizer elsewhere, the manure may be contaminated with bacteria which can infect humans.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zhang|first=Sarah|title=Pig-manure fertilizer linked to human MRSA infections|journal=Nature News|doi=10.1038/nature.2013.13752|ref=harv|doi-access=free}}</ref>
Studies have also shown that direct contact with livestock can lead to the spread of antibiotic-resistant bacteria from animals to humans.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Casey JA |displayauthors=etal | year = 2013 | title = High-Density Livestock Operations, Crop Field Application of Manure, and Risk of Community-Associated Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus Infection in Pennsylvania | url = | journal = JAMA Internal Medicine | volume = 173 | issue = 21| pages = 1980–1990 | doi=10.1001/jamainternmed.2013.10408| pmc = 4372690}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chang|first1=Qiuzhi|last2=Wang|first2=Weike|last3=Regev‐Yochay|first3=Gili|last4=Lipsitch|first4=Marc|last5=Hanage|first5=William P.|date=1 March 2015|title=Antibiotics in agriculture and the risk to human health: how worried should we be?|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/eva.12185|journal=Evolutionary Applications|volume=8|issue=3|pages=240–247|doi=10.1111/eva.12185|issn=1752-4571|ref=harv}}</ref>
Sampling of retail meats such as turkey, chicken, pork and beef consistently show high levels of Enterobacteriaceae. Rates of resistant bacteria in these meats are high as well. Sources on contaminated meat put humans at direct risk by handling the meat or ingesting it before it is completely cooked.<ref name=":32" /> Ingesting contaminated meat sources accounts for 20% of antibiotic-resistant infections in humans. [[Food preservation]] methods can help eliminate, decrease, or prevent the growth of bacteria. Evidence for the transfer of [[macrolide]]-resistant microorganisms from animals to humans has been scant, and most evidence shows that pathogens of concern in human populations originated in humans and are maintained there, with rare cases of transference to humans.<ref name="pmid15151237">{{cite journal|last1=Hurd|first1=H. Scott|last2=Doores|first2=Stephanie|last3=Hayes|first3=Dermot|last4=Mathew|first4=Alan|last5=Maurer|first5=John|last6=Silley|first6=Peter|last7=Singer|first7=Randall S.|last8=Jones|first8=Ronald N.|date=1 May 2004|title=Public Health Consequences of Macrolide Use in Food Animals: A Deterministic Risk Assessment|url=http://jfoodprotection.org/doi/pdf/10.4315/0362-028X-67.5.980?code=FOPR-site|journal=Journal of Food Protection|volume=67|issue=5|pages=980–992|doi=10.4315/0362-028X-67.5.980|issn=0362-028X|pmid=15151237|via=}}</ref><ref name="pmid18643826">{{cite journal|last1=Hurd|first1=H. Scott|last2=Malladi|first2=Sasidhar|date=June 2008|title=A stochastic assessment of the public health risks of the use of macrolide antibiotics in food animals|url=https://www.sandersonfarms.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/PDF-5-Hurd_et_al-2008-Risk_Analysis.pdf|journal=Risk Analysis: An Official Publication of the Society for Risk Analysis|volume=28|issue=3|pages=695–710|doi=10.1111/j.1539-6924.2008.01054.x|issn=1539-6924|pmid=18643826|ref=harv}}</ref>
==Research into alternatives== Increasing concern due to the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria has led researchers to look for alternatives to using antibiotics in livestock.<ref name=Allen>{{cite journal | author = Allen H. K. | author2=Trachsel J. | author3= Looft T. | author4= Casey T. A. | year = 2014 | title = Finding alternatives to antibiotics | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/nyas.12468/epdf | journal = Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences | volume = 1323 | issue = | pages = 91–100 | pmid = 24953233 | doi=10.1111/nyas.12468}}</ref>
[[Probiotics]], cultures of a single bacteria strain or mixture of different strains, are being studied in livestock as a production enhancer.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Hume M. E. | year = 2011 | title = Historic perspective: Prebiotics, probiotics, and other alternatives to antibiotics | url = http://naldc.nal.usda.gov/download/57525/PDF | journal = Poultry Science | volume = 90 | issue = 11| pages = 2663–9 | pmid = 22010256 | doi=10.3382/ps.2010-01030}}</ref>
[[Prebiotics]] are non-digestible carbohydrates. The carbohydrates are mainly made up of oligosaccharides which are short chains of monosaccharides. The two most commonly studied prebiotics are fructooligosaccharides (FOS) and mannanoligosaccharides (MOS). FOS has been studied for use in chicken feed. MOS works as a competitive binding site, as bacteria bind to it rather than the intestine and are carried out.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Griggs J. P. | author2= Jacob J. P. | year = 2005 | title = Alternatives to Antibiotics for Organic Poultry Production | url = https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jacquie_Jacob/publication/228649989_Alternatives_to_antibiotics_for_organic_poultry_production/links/542404860cf238c6ea6e8707.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Poultry Science | volume = 14 | issue = | pages = 750–756 | doi=10.1093/japr/14.4.750}}</ref>
[[Bacteriophages]] are able to infect most bacteria and are easily found in most environments colonized by bacteria, and have been studied as well.<ref name=Allen/>
In another study it was found that using probiotics, competitive exclusion, enzymes, immunomodulators and organic acids prevents the spread of bacteria and can all be used in place of antibiotics.<ref>Doyle, M.E. 2001: Alternatives to Antibiotic Use for Growth Promotion in Animal Husbandry. Food Research Institute, University of Wisconsin-Madison.</ref> Another research team was able to use bacteriocins, antimicrobial peptides and bacteriophages in the control of bacterial infections.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Joerger R.D. | year = 2003 | title = Alternatives to antibiotics: bacteriocins, antimicrobial peptides and bacteriophages | url = | journal = Poultry Science | volume = 82 | issue = 4| pages = 640–647 | doi=10.1093/ps/82.4.640}}</ref> While further research is needed in this field, alternative methods have been identified in effectively controlling bacterial infections in animals. All of the alternative methods listed pose no known threat to human health and all can lead the elimination of antibiotics in factory farms. With further research it is highly likely that a cost effective and health effective alternative could and will be found.

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2015}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Nimbin Aquarius Festival | image = | caption = | location = [[Canberra]], [[Nimbin, New South Wales|Nimbin]] | years_active = 1971, 1973 | founders = Johnny Allen and [[Graeme Dunstan]] | promoter = | dates = 12 to 23 May 1973 | genre = | website = }} The '''Nimbin Aquarius Festival''' was a [[Counterculture|counter-cultural]] arts and [[music festival]] organised by the [[Australian Union of Students]]. It was the fourth in a biannual series of festivals, first organised by the National Union of Australian University Students (NUAUS). The First Australian Universities Arts Festival was held in [[Sydney]] in 1967, and the Second Australian Universities Arts Festival was held in [[Melbourne]] in 1969. The third added "Aquarius" to its name and was held in Canberra in 1971.<ref>[http://www.milesago.com/festivals/aquarius71.htm Festivals - Aquarius Festival, Canberra, 1971] MilesAgo. (Retrieved 26 October 2006)</ref> The fourth and last was held in [[Nimbin, New South Wales|Nimbin]], [[New South Wales]] in 1973.<ref>[http://www.milesago.com/festivals/aquarius73.htm Festivals - Aquarius Festival, Nimbin, 1973] MilesAgo. (Retrieved 26 October 2006)</ref>
The Aquarius Festival aimed to celebrate alternative thinking and [[sustainable lifestyle]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.echonews.com/index.php?page=View%20Article&article=21065&issue=332 |title=Rainbow Region born from black and white |author=S Sorrensen |accessdate=2009-11-03 |date= |work=The Northern Rivers Echo |publisher=TAOW Ltd }}</ref> The ten-day event was held from 12 to 23 May 1973 and co-directed by Johnny Allen and [[Graeme Dunstan]]. [[Vernon Treweeke]] also played a part in organising the event. It is often described as Australia's equivalent to the [[Woodstock Festival]] and the birthplace for Australia's [[History of the hippie movement|hippie movement]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/news/relationships/peace-love-and-real-life/2008/03/14/1205472071315.html?page=2 |title=Peace, love and real life |accessdate=2009-11-03 |date=14 March 2008 |work=[[Brisbane Times]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Digital]] }}</ref> Estimated turn-up at Nimbin was from 5,000 to 10,000 people.
==Performers== Performers at the festival included the White Company - an experimental Theatre Troupe featuring a number of alternative culture artists including [[Peter Carolan]] - singer Paul Joseph, Donny McCormack (ex-Nutwood Rug Band), The Larrikins and Ian Farr. Also appearing were the South African pianist Dollar Brand (later known as [[Abdullah Ibrahim]]), and tightrope walker and unicyclist [[Philippe Petit]], who gained worldwide fame the following year by walking between the rooftops of the Twin Towers at the World Trade Center.
==Legacy== The festival had a permanent effect on the economy of Nimbin, as many Festival participants decided to remain in the district<ref name="smh">{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/New-South-Wales/Nimbin/2005/02/17/1108500198341.html |title=Nimbin - New South Wales - Australia - Travel |author= |accessdate=2009-11-03 |date=8 February 2004 |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Digital]] | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091014055624/http://www.smh.com.au/news/New-South-Wales/Nimbin/2005/02/17/1108500198341.html| archivedate= 14 October 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The area was previously a dairying and banana growing region in severe decline. Some of those that stayed might be defined as [[hippies]], but in fact the larger percentage came from all sorts of backgrounds and life experience, ranging from 18 to 80.
One group pooled resources after the Nimbin Aquarius Festival and bought a then {{convert|1200|acre|ha|order=flip|adj=on|sigfig=1}} property at [[Tuntable Falls, New South Wales|Tuntable Falls]]<ref name="smh"/> in the next valley east, below [[Mount Nardi]], and formed a community called the "Co-Ordination Co-Operative". Other groups followed suit and formed [[commune (intentional community)|commune]]s that continue today. Examples include Paradise Valley Pastoral Company and Nmbngee.<ref name="smh"/>
While "Multiple Occupancy" was basically a cheap housing alternative, there were some self-described spiritual communities that shared particular values, like Bodhi Farm and Darmananda, but they tended to be closer to the neighbouring [[The Channon, New South Wales|The Channon]] and Terania Creek than Nimbin.
[[Mullumbimby, New South Wales|Mullumbimby]] and [[Byron Bay, New South Wales|Byron Bay]] attracted more of the moneyed "[[New Age]]" people, while Nimbin attracted impecunious wanderers and back-packers. Within a decade the "Aquarians" were outnumbered by the continuing flow of disaffected urbanites and tree-changers coming into the area.
Interviews were conducted in 1992 documenting the alternative lifestyle movement of Northern NSW in the 1970s focusing on the town of Nimbin and the 1973 Aquarius Festival. Interviewees discussed how they arrived in Nimbin, their efforts in organising the Aquarius Festival, and the lasting impact the Festival had on the township.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://primo-slnsw.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/primo-explore/fulldisplay?docid=ADLIB110317356&context=L&vid=SLNSW&search_scope=EEA&tab=default_tab&lang=en_US|title=Richmond-Tweed Oral History Group - Under the Rainbow. Interviews with residents following alternative life styles in the Lismore area, 1992|last=|first=|date=|website=State Library of New South Wales Catalogue|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 June 2018}}</ref>
At the 10th anniversary of the Aquarius Festival, the [[Australian Association of Sustainable Communities]] (AASC) was formed.
