|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/previews/the-full-breakdown-on-league-of-legends-spectator-mode/ |title=The full breakdown on League of Legends' Spectator Mode |publisher=PC Gamer |author=Lucas Sullivan |date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
In response to the release of [[virtual reality headset]]s in 2016, some games, such as ''Dota 2'', were updated to include virtual reality spectating support.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thursten |first1=Chris |title=Dota 2 Battle Pass update adds crazy new VR spectator mode |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/dota-2-battle-pass-update-adds-crazy-new-vr-spectator-mode/ |website=PC Gamer |accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref>
===Online=== A very common method for connection is the [[Internet]]. Game servers are often separated by region, but high quality connections allow players to set up real-time connections across the world. Downsides to online connections include increased difficulty detecting [[Cheating in online games|cheating]] compared to physical events, and greater [[Latency (engineering)|network latency]], which can negatively impact players' performance, especially at high levels of competition. Many competitions take place online, especially for smaller tournaments and [[exhibition game]]s.
Since the 1990s, professional teams or organized [[clan (computer gaming)|clans]] have set up matches via [[Internet Relay Chat]] networks such as [[QuakeNet]]. As esports have developed, it has also become common for players to use automated matchmaking clients built into the games themselves. This was popularized by the 1996 release of [[Blizzard Entertainment|Blizzard's]] [[Battle.net]], which has been integrated into both the ''[[Warcraft (series)|Warcraft]]'' and ''[[StarCraft (series)|StarCraft]]'' series. Automated matchmaking has become commonplace in console gaming as well, with services such as [[Xbox Live]] and the [[PlayStation Network]]. After competitors have contacted each other, the game is often managed by a [[game server]], either remotely to each of the competitors, or running on one of the competitor's machines.
===Local area network=== {{further|LAN Party}} Additionally, competitions are also often conducted over a [[local area network]] or LAN. The smaller network usually has very little [[lag]] and higher [[Quality of service|quality]]. Because competitors must be physically present, LANs help ensure fair play by allowing direct scrutiny of competitors. This helps prevent many forms of cheating, such as unauthorized hardware or software [[modding]]. The physical presence of competitors helps create a more social atmosphere at LAN events. Many gamers organize [[LAN parties]] or visit [[Internet café]]s, and most major tournaments are conducted over LANs.
Individual games have taken various approaches to LAN support. In contrast to the original ''[[StarCraft]]'', ''[[StarCraft II]]'' was released without support for LAN play, drawing some strongly negative reactions from players.<ref>{{cite web |title=Why StarCraft II Still Doesn't Support Local Multiplayer |url=http://kotaku.com/5919892/why-starcraft-ii-still-doesnt-support-local-multiplayer |publisher=Kotaku |date=20 June 2012 |accessdate=7 September 2013 |author=Jason Schreier}}</ref> ''League of Legends'' was originally released for online play only, but announced in October 2012 that a LAN client was in the works for use in major tournaments.<ref>{{cite web |title=League of Legends LAN version in development at Riot Games, Mac client news coming |url=http://www.polygon.com/2012/10/17/3515164/league-of-legends-lan-version-in-development-at-riot-games-mac-client |date=12 October 2012 |author=Michael McWhertor |publisher=Polygon |accessdate=7 September 2013}}</ref> In September 2013, Valve added general support for LAN play to ''[[Dota 2]]'' in a patch for the game.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.techinasia.com/dota-2-update-lan-feature-worth-excited/ |title=DOTA 2 update: Why the LAN feature is something worth being excited about |author=Xairylle |publisher=TechInAsia |date=20 September 2013 |accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref>
==Tournaments== {{see also|List of esports leagues and tournaments}}
[[File:Goście Intel Extreme Masters (8465481816).jpg|thumb|left|Casual players at the 2013 [[Intel Extreme Masters]] in [[Katowice]], [[Poland]]]] Esports tournaments are almost always physical events in which occur in front of a live audience. The tournament may be part of a larger gathering, such as [[Dreamhack]], or the competition may be the entirety of the event, like the [[World Cyber Games]]. Competitions take several formats, but the most common are [[Single-elimination tournament|single]] or [[Double-elimination tournament|double elimination]], sometimes hybridized with [[Round-robin tournament|group stage]]. Competitions usually have referees or officials to monitor for cheating.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gotfrag.com/portal/story/40273/ |title=GotFrag eSports - All Games News Story - TF2 Referees Wanted |publisher=Gotfrag.com |date=10 October 2007 |accessdate=4 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528203921/http://www.gotfrag.com/portal/story/40273 |archivedate=28 May 2012}}</ref>
Although competitions involving video games have long existed, esports underwent a significant transition in the late 1990s. Beginning with the [[Cyberathlete Professional League]] in 1997, tournaments became much larger, and [[sponsor (commercial)|corporate sponsorship]] became more common. Increasing viewership both in person and online brought esports to a wider audience.<ref name="2012Forbes">{{cite web |title=2012: The Year of eSports |publisher=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2012/12/20/2012-the-year-of-esports/ |date=20 December 2012 |author=Paul Tassi |accessdate=15 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/0808/p13s01-alsp.html?entryBottomStory |title=Are video games a sport? |publisher=CS Monitor |author=Gloria Goodale |date=8 August 2003 |accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref> Major tournaments include the [[World Cyber Games]], the North American [[Major League Gaming]] league, the France-based [[Electronic Sports World Cup]], and the [[World e-Sports Games]] held in [[Hangzhou, China]].
For well established games, total prize money can amount to millions of U.S. dollars a year.<ref name=lolprizepool /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.esfiworld.com/news/nasl-s3-finals-push-sc2-earnings-over-5m |title=NASL S3 Finals push SC2 earnings over $5m |author=David Schmidt |date=16 July 2012 |publisher=ESFI World |accessdate=22 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212160245/http://archive.esfiworld.com/news/nasl-s3-finals-push-sc2-earnings-over-5m |archivedate=12 December 2013}}</ref> As of 10 September 2016, ''Dota 2'' has awarded approximately US$86 million in prize money within 632 registered tournaments, with 23 players winning over $1 million. ''League of Legends'' awarded approximately $30 million within 1749 registered tournaments, but in addition to the prize money, [[Riot Games]] provides salaries for players within their [[League of Legends Championship Series|''League of Legends'' Championship Series]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gamurs.com/articles/comparing-the-potential-earnings-of-lcs-players-to-professional-streamers |title=Comparing the potential earnings of LCS PLayers to Professional Streamers |website=GAMURS |date=27 October 2014}}</ref> Nonetheless, there has been criticism to how these salaries are distributed, since most players earn a fairly low wage but a few top players have a significantly higher salary, skewing the average earning per player.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://krbnu.tumblr.com/post/135814946168/kespa-responds-to-kocca-pro-gamer-salary-data-10 |title=KeSPA Responds to KOCCA Pro Gamer Salary Data… 10 Players Over $85,241. |website=LCK Translation Archive |date=24 December 2015 |accessdate=10 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406101703/http://krbnu.tumblr.com/post/135814946168/kespa-responds-to-kocca-pro-gamer-salary-data-10 |archivedate=6 April 2016 }}</ref> In August 2017, [[The International 2017]], Valve's premier ''Dota 2'' tournament, was held and broke records by having the largest prize pool to date for an esports tournament, amounting to over US$24 million.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Prescott |first1=Shaun |title=The Dota 2 International prize pool has comfortably broken its record |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/the-dota-2-international-prize-pool-has-comfortably-broken-its-record/ |website=PC Gamer |accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref>
Often, game developers provide prize money for tournament competition directly,<ref name="lolprizepool">{{cite web |url=http://pc.ign.com/articles/122/1224149p1.html |title=League of Legends Season 2 Championship Announced |author=Andrew Goldfarb |date=1 May 2012 |publisher=IGN |accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref> but sponsorship may also come from third parties, typically companies selling [[computer hardware]], [[energy drink]]s, or [[computer software]]. Generally, hosting a large esports event is not profitable as a stand-alone venture.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/9/30/4719766/twitch-raises-20-million-esports-market-booming |title=Field of streams: how Twitch made video games a spectator sport |publisher=TheVerge |author=Ben Popper |date=30 September 2013 |accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref> For example, Riot has stated that their headline ''League of Legends'' Championship Series is "a significant investment that we're not making money from".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pcgamesn.com/leagueoflegends/lcs-significant-investment-we-re-not-making-money-riot-love-it-anyway |title=LCS "a significant investment that we're not making money from", but Riot love it anyway |publisher=PCGamesN |author=robzacny |date=21 August 2013 |accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref>
There is considerable variation and negotiation over the relationship between [[video game developers]] and tournament organizers and broadcasters. While the original ''StarCraft'' events emerged in South Korea largely independently of Blizzard, the company decided to require organizers and broadcasters to authorize events featuring the sequel ''StarCraft II''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edge-online.com/features/battle-starcraft-ii/ |publisher=Edge-Online |title=The battle for StarCraft II |date=11 November 2010 |author=Edge Staff |accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> In the short term, this led to a deadlock with the [[Korean e-Sports Association]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gosugamers.net/starcraft/news/10265-blizzard-vs-kespa-the-ultimate-fight |title=Blizzard VS. Kespa, the Ultimate fight |author=Simon "Go0g3n" |publisher=Gosu Gamers |year=2009 |accessdate=18 September 2013}}</ref> An agreement was reached in 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pikigeek.com/2012/05/02/kespa-ogn-blizzard-and-gomtv-join-horses-for-starcraft-ii/ |title=KeSPA, OGN, Blizzard and GOMtv Join Horses for StarCraft II |publisher=PikiGeek |date=2 May 2012 |author=Jeroen Amin |accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> Blizzard requires authorization for tournaments with more than $10,000 USD in prizes.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bnetcmsus-a.akamaihd.net/cms/gallery/4RL7ZGLM5EF21374101567640.pdf |format=PDF |title=Tournament Guidelines Document |publisher=Blizzard |date=6 June 2013 |accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> [[Riot Games]] offers in-game rewards to authorized tournaments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/community/prized-events |title=Prized Events |publisher=Riot |accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref>
eSport competitions have also become a popular feature at gaming and multi-genre [[Fan convention|conventions]].{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
== Training == The training that the players must undergo to prepare for tournaments is different but still takes a tremendous amount of time. Athletes from traditional sports' training is almost entirely based on honing their physical prowess in performing that sport, such as muscle memory, exercising, and dieting. Esports athletes' training is much more based on training the mind, such as studying strategies and new updates for the game. Team Liquid, a professional League of Legends team, practice for a minimum of 50 hours per week and most play the game far more.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/pro-gamers-explain-the-insane-training-regimen-they-use-to-stay-on-top-2015-5|title=Here's the insane training schedule of a 20-something professional gamer|work=Business Insider|access-date=5 April 2018}}</ref> This training schedule for players has resulted in many of them retiring a very early age. Few careers burn as intensely—and as briefly—as that of an esports professional. Players are generally in competition by their mid- to late teens, and most are retired by their mid-20s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/espn/story/_/id/13053116/esports-athletes-put-hours-training-reach-pinnacle|title=Inside an eSports training regimen|work=ESPN.com|access-date=5 April 2018}}</ref> Because of this people in the industry are discussing the possibility of implementing physical workouts in addition to the mental training they already go through.
==Teams and associations== Professional gamers, or "pro gamers", are often associated with gaming teams and/or broader gaming associations. Teams like [[FaZe Clan]], [[OpTic Gaming]], [[Evil Geniuses]], [[Team SoloMid]], [[Cloud9 (eSports)|Cloud9]], [[Fnatic]], [[Mineski-Dota|Mineski]], [[Counter Logic Gaming]], [[SK Telecom T1]], [[Splyce]], [[Team EnVyUs]], and [[Natus Vincere]] consist of several professionals. In addition to prize money from tournament wins, players may also be paid a separate team salary. Team sponsorship may cover tournament travel expenses or gaming hardware. Prominent esports sponsors include companies such as [[Logitech]] and [[Razer USA|Razer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esfiworld.com/interview-with-razers-global-e-sports-manager-the-business-behind-sponsoring-teams/ |title=Interview with Razer's global e-sports manager: The business behind sponsoring teams |author=Brent Ruiz |date=3 February 2013 |publisher=ESFI World |accessdate=10 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822230651/http://www.esfiworld.com/interview-with-razers-global-e-sports-manager-the-business-behind-sponsoring-teams/ |archivedate=22 August 2013 }}</ref> Teams feature these sponsors on their website, team jerseys<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.customesports.com |title=Custom Esports Jerseys and Apparel |date=|access-date= |website= |publisher= |last= |first=}}</ref> and on their social media, in 2016 the biggest teams have social media followings of over a million.<ref>{{Cite web |title=OpTic Gaming™ (@OpTicGaming) {{!}} Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/OpTicGaming|website=twitter.com|access-date=27 January 2016}}</ref> Associations include the [[Korean e-Sports Association]] (KeSPA), the [[International e-Sports Federation]] (IeSF), the [[British eSports Association|British esports Association]], and the [[World eSports Association|World esports Association]] (WESA).
Some traditional sporting athletes have invested in esports, such as [[Rick Fox]]'s ownership of [[Echo Fox]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-18/former-nba-player-rick-fox-buys-esports-team-gravity |title=Former NBA Player Rick Fox Buys eSports Team Gravity |first=Scott |last=Soshnick |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=18 December 2015 |accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref> [[Jeremy Lin]]'s ownership of [[Team VGJ]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Allen|first1=Eric|title=Jeremy Lin endorses new Dota 2 team VGJ|url=http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/17579673/jeremy-lin-endorse-new-dota-2-team-vgj|website=ESPN|accessdate=5 October 2016}}</ref> [[Shaquille O'Neal]]'s investment in [[NRG Esports]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/17209251/shaq-nrg-esports-pick-overwatch-team |title=Shaq, NRG Esports pick up Overwatch team |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> Some association football teams, such as [[FC Schalke 04]] in Germany,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/esports/story/_/id/15552685/soccer-org-schalke-04-finalizes-league-championship-series-roster-picks-fox |title=Sources: Soccer org Schalke 04 finalizes League Championship Series roster, picks up Fox |work=espn.com}}</ref> [[Paris Saint-Germain eSports|Paris Saint-Germain esports]] in France;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/paris-saint-germain/story/2977336/psg-unveil-first-three-signings-in-ambitious-esports-venture |title=PSG unveil first three signings in ambitious eSports venture |first=Jonathan |last=Johnson |date=20 October 2016 |accessdate=5 November 2016 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> [[Besiktas JK]], [[Fenerbahce S.K.]], and [[Galatasaray]] in Turkey; [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] in Greece either sponsor or have complete ownership in esports teams.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Espor nedir? Bora Koçyiğit Fanatik'e anlattı!|url=http://www.fanatik.com.tr/2017/04/06/espor-nedir-bora-kocyigit-fanatik-e-anlatti-1286961|access-date=17 January 2018}}</ref>
==Ethics and legal problems== {{further|Professional ethics}} Pro gamers are usually obligated to behave ethically, abiding by both the explicit rules set out by tournaments, associations, and teams, as well as following general expectations of good [[sportsmanship]]. For example, it is common practice and considered good etiquette to chat "gg" (for "good game") when defeated.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.techhive.com/article/248526/web_jargon_origins_revealed.html |title=Web Jargon Origins Revealed |author=David Daw |publisher=TechHive |date=21 January 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref> Many games rely on the fact competitors have limited information about the game state. In a prominent example of good conduct, during a 2012 [[Intel Extreme Masters|IEM]] ''StarCraft II'' game, the players Feast and DeMusliM both voluntarily offered information about their strategies to negate the influence of outside information inadvertently leaked to "Feast" during the game.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cadred.org/News/Article/167534/ |title=IEM Sao Paolo: Manner Bear Conflict |publisher=Cadred |author=Victor Meulendijks |date=8 February 2012 |accessdate=8 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131008224558/http://www.cadred.org/News/Article/167534/ |archivedate=8 October 2013 }}</ref> Players in some leagues have been reprimanded for failure to comply with expectations of good behavior. In 2012 professional ''League of Legends'' player Christian "IWillDominate" Riviera was banned from competing for a period of one year following a history of verbal abuse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=2864421 |title=IWillDominate Tribunal Permaban & eSports Competition Ruling |date=4 December 2012 |accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> In 2013 ''StarCraft II'' progamer [[Greg "Idra" Fields]] was fired from [[Evil Geniuses]] for insulting his fans on the [[Team Liquid]] internet forums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teamliquid.net/forum/viewmessage.php?topic_id=411840 |title=Evil Geniuses Releases Greg "IdrA" Fields |author=Alexander Garfield |publisher=TeamLiquid |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=8 January 2014}}</ref> ''League of Legends'' players Mithy and Nukeduck received similar penalties in 2014 after behaving in a "toxic" manner during matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/league-of-legends-pro-players-banned-for-toxic-behavior/1100-6420072/ |title=League of Legends Pro Players Banned for "Toxic Behavior" |date=3 June 2014 |accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref>
Team Siren, an all-female ''[[League of Legends]]'' team, was formed in June 2013. The announcement of the team was met with controversy, being dismissed as a "gimmick" to attract the attention of men.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Gz9um3wV1o |title=Introducing Team Siren - YouTube |date=30 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rtsguru.com/game/435/article/5991/Why-Team-Siren-Matters.html |title=Why Team Siren Matters |date=10 June 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref> The team disbanded within a month, due to the negative publicity of their promotional video, as well as the poor attitude of the team captain towards her teammates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?p=38929204#post38929204 |title=Siren broke up (with proof) - Page 16 - League of Legends Community |date=19 June 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gameskinny.com/hzi5j/league-of-legends-team-siren-disbands-valuable-lessons-learned |title=League of Legends Team Siren Disbands: Valuable Lessons Learned - League of Legends |date=26 June 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref>
There have been serious violations of the rules. In 2010, eleven ''StarCraft: Brood War'' players were found guilty of [[StarCraft professional competition#Match fixing scandal|fixing matches for profit]], and were fined and banned from future competition. [[Team Curse]] and [[Team Dignitas]] were denied prize money for collusion during the [[2012 MLG Summer Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pcgamesn.com/leagueoflegends/league-legends-curse-na-and-team-dignitas-disqualified-mlg-summer-championship-no-first-or-second-place-awarded |title=League of Legends' Curse NA and Team Dignitas disqualified from MLG Summer Championship, no first or second place awarded |author=Jeremy Peel |publisher=PC GamesN |date=27 August 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref> In 2012, ''League of Legends'' team Azubu Frost was fined US$30,000 for cheating during a semifinal match of the world playoffs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/riot-fines-league-of-legends-cheaters-30000-6398055 |title=Riot fines League of Legends cheaters $30,000 |author=Laura Parker |publisher=GameSpot |date=10 October 2012 |accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref> ''Dota 2'' player Aleksey "Solo" Berezin was suspended from a number of tournaments for intentionally throwing a game in order to collect $322 from online gambling.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.joindota.com/en/news/10165-solo-out-of-rox-kis |title=Solo out of Rox.KIS |author=Sun_tzu |publisher=joinDota |date=21 June 2013 |accessdate=3 July 2014}}</ref> In 2014, four high-profile North American ''Counter-Strike'' players from iBuyPower, namely Sam "DaZeD" Marine, Braxton "swag" Pierce, Joshua "steel" Nissan and Keven "AZK" Lariviere were suspended from official tournaments after they had been found guilty of match-fixing. The four players had allegedly profited over US$10,000 through betting on their fixed matches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/valve-bans-pro-counter-strike-teams-for-match-fixi/1100-6424901/ |title=Valve Bans Pro Counter-Strike Teams For Match Fixing |work=GameSpot |accessdate=2 September 2015}}</ref> [[Skin gambling|Gambling on esports using ''Counter-Strike: Global Offense'' "skins"]], worth an estimated US$2.3 billion in 2015, had come under criticism in June and July 2016 after several questionable legal and ethical aspects of the practice were discovered.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-36824689 |title=Valve tackles Counter Strike gambling sites |work=[[BBC]] |date=21 July 2016 |accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref>
===Performance-enhancing drugs=== Reports of widespread use of [[performance-enhancing drugs]] (PEDs) in esports are not uncommon, with players discussing their own, their teammates' and their competitors' use and officials acknowledging the prevalence of the issue.<ref name="parkin">{{cite web |last1=Parkin |first1=Simon |title=Winners might use drugs |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-04-08-winners-might-use-drugs |accessdate=19 July 2015 |publisher=[[Eurogamer]] |date=8 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="newscientist">{{cite web |last1=Hodson |first1=Hal |title=Esports: Doping is rampant, industry insider claims |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn26051-esports-doping-is-rampant-industry-insider-claims#.U-x3KvldU0J |accessdate=19 July 2015 |publisher=[[New Scientist]] |date=18 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="summers">{{cite web |last1=Summers |first1=Nick |title=Top 'Counter-Strike' player admits eSports has a doping problem |url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/07/17/esports-adderall-doping/ |accessdate=19 July 2015 |publisher=[[Engadget]] |date=17 July 2015}}</ref> Players often turn to [[stimulants]] such as [[Ritalin]], [[Adderall]] and [[Vyvanse]], drugs which can significantly boost concentration, improve reaction time and prevent fatigue.<ref name=parkin /> [[Selegiline]], a drug used to treat [[Parkinson's disease]], is reportedly popular because, like stimulants, it enhances mood and motivation. Conversely, drugs with calming effects are also sought after. Some players take [[propanolol]], which blocks the effects of [[adrenaline]], or [[Valium]], which is prescribed to treat [[anxiety disorder]], in order to remain calm under pressure.<ref name=newscientist /> According to Bjoern Franzen, a former [[SK Gaming]] executive, it is second nature for some ''League of Legends'' players to take as many as three different drugs before competition.<ref name="elephant">{{cite web |last1=Franzen |first1=Bjoern |title=Doping in eSports – The almost invisible Elephant in the room |url=http://bjoernfranzen.com/blog/doping-in-esports-the-almost-invisible-elephant-in-the-room |accessdate=19 July 2015 |work=BjoernFranzen.com |date=14 August 2014}}</ref> In July 2015 Kory "Semphis" Friesen, an ex-[[Cloud9 (esports)|Cloud9]] player, admitted that he and his teammates were all using Adderall during a match against [[Virtus.pro]] in the [[ESL One Katowice 2015]] ''Counter-Strike: Global Offensive'' tournament, and went on to claim that "everyone" at [[ESEA League]] tournaments uses Adderall.<ref name=summers />
The unregulated use of such drugs poses severe risks to competitors' health, including [[addiction]], [[overdose]], [[serotonin syndrome]] and, in the case of stimulants, [[weight loss]].<ref name=parkin /><ref name=newscientist /> Even over-the-counter [[energy drinks]] which are marketed specifically toward gamers have faced media and regulatory scrutiny due to deaths and hospitalizations.<ref name="fuel">{{cite web |last1=Stout |first1=Hilary |title=Selling the Young on ‘Gaming Fuel’ |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/20/business/energy-drink-industry-under-scrutiny-looks-to-gamers-to-keep-sales-surging.html |accessdate=19 July 2015 |work=The New York Times |date=19 May 2015}}</ref> Accordingly, Adderall and other such stimulants are banned and their use penalized by many professional sporting bodies and leagues, including [[Major League Baseball]] and the [[National Football League]]. Although [[International e-Sports Federation]] (IeSF) is a signatory of the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]], the governing body has not outlawed any PEDs in its sanctioned competitions.<ref name=parkin /> Action has been taken on the individual league level, however, as at least one major league, the [[Electronic Sports League]], has made use of any drugs during matches punishable by expulsion from competition.<ref>{{cite web |title=ESL Major Series One Rulebook |url=http://gfx.esl-europe.net/gfx/media/eu/emsone/summer2013/ESL_Major_Series_One_Rulebook.pdf |publisher=[[Electronic Sports League]] |accessdate=19 July 2015}}</ref> Although not all players use drugs, it is common to see gamers use energy boosters or drinks. They commonly drink caffeinated drinks or use energy pills.
===Player exploitation=== There has been some concern over the quality of life and potential mistreatment of players by organizations, especially in South Korea. Korean organizations have been accused of refusing to pay competitive salaries, leading to a slow exodus of Korean players to other markets. In an interview, ''League of Legends'' player Bae "Dade" Eo-jin said that "Korean players wake up at 1pm and play until 5am", and suggested that the 16 hour play schedule was a significant factor in causing [[Burnout (psychology)|burnout]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://na.lolesports.com/articles/koreas-pro-exodus-may-spell-bad-news-games-top-region |title=KOREA'S PRO EXODUS MAY SPELL BAD NEWS FOR THE GAME'S TOP REGION |publisher=Riot Games |author=Frank 'Riot Mirhi' Fields |date=5 November 2014 |accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> Concerns over the [[mental health]] of players intensified in 2014 when ''League of Legends'' player Cheon "Promise" Min-Ki attempted suicide a week after admitting to [[match fixing]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/3/18/5522192/korean-league-of-legends-player-fixed-matches-suicide |title=Top Korean League of Legends player fixed matches before attempting suicide, says eSports league |publisher=Polygon |author=Owen S. Good |date=18 March 2014 |accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref>
To combat the negative environment, Korean ''League of Legends'' teams were given new rules for the upcoming 2015 season by Riot Games, including the adoption of minimum salaries for professional players, requiring contracts and allowing players to stream individually for additional player revenue.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ongamers.com/articles/major-changes-heading-to-korea-for-the-2015-season/1100-2303/ |title=Major changes heading to Korea for the 2015 season |publisher=OnGamers |author=Travis Gafford |date=27 October 2014 |accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref>
Players must handle their own treatments and carry their own medical insurance, which is opposite of the norm with professional sports teams. Since most esports play requires many actions per minute, some players may get [[repetitive strain]] injuries, causing hand or wrist pain.<ref>Luke Winkie (31 May 2016) [http://www.vocativ.com/323427/the-esports-injury-crisis/ The eSports Injury Crisis] Vocativ, Retrieved 3 June 2016.</ref>
===Economics=== [[League of Legends Championship Series|''League of Legends'' Championship Series]] and [[League of Legends Champions Korea|''League of Legends'' Champions Korea]] offer guaranteed [[salaries]] for players.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsoflegends.com/index.php/official-2015-season-lol-esports-league-reform-plan-announced-final-version-29648/ |title=Official 2015 Season LoL eSports League Reform Plan Announced (Final Version) |website=News of Legends |date=11 November 2014 |author=Caymus |accessdate=28 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518084152/http://www.newsoflegends.com/index.php/official-2015-season-lol-esports-league-reform-plan-announced-final-version-29648/ |archivedate=18 May 2015 }}</ref> Despite this, online streaming is preferred by some players, as it is in some cases more profitable than competing with a team and streamers have the ability to determine their own schedule. The International tournament awards US$10 million to the winners, however teams that do not have the same amount of success often do not have financial stability and frequently break up after failing to win.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/dota-2-prize-distribution-players/ |title=Dota 2 is the richest of the big esports, but its players are the poorest |date=13 August 2014 |website=[[The Daily Dot]] |accessdate=2 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518071207/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/dota-2-prize-distribution-players/ |archivedate=18 May 2015 }}</ref>
In 2015 it was estimated by SuperData Research that the global esports industry generated revenue of around US$748.8 million that year. Asia is the leading esports market with over $321 million in revenue, North America is around $224 million, and Europe has $172 million and the rest of the world for about $29 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fortune.com/2015/10/28/global-esports-revenues-nearing-2-billion/ |title=Global esports revenues are nearing 2 billion |first=John |last=Gaudiosi |website=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=28 October 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref> Global esports revenue is estimated to reach $1.9 billion by 2018.
The number of female viewers has been growing in esports, with an estimated 30% of esports viewers being female in 2013, an increase from 15% from the previous year.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} However, despite the increase in female viewers, there is not a growth of female players in high level competitive esports.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} The top female players that are involved in esports mainly get exposure in female-only tournaments, most notably ''Counter-Strike'', ''[[Dead or Alive 4]]'', and ''StarCraft II''. All-female esports teams include [[Frag Dolls]] and [[PMS Clan]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}
===Gambling=== {{expand section|date=June 2018}}
Gambling and betting on esport matches have generally been illegal in major markets. The illegality of esport gambling has created a [[black market]] related to esports and virtual currency, as these go unregulated, may encourage match-fixing by players themselves, and lead to concerns about underage gambling due to the draw of video games. One such example of this is [[skin gambling]], where virtual items earned in games were used as a currency for users to bet on the outcome of matches.<ref name="wapost betting"/>
Esports gambling in the United States has been illegal under the federal [[Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act of 1992]] (PASPA) until May 2018. The Act prevented all but five states from allowing gambling on sporting events.<ref name="wapost betting"/> However, regulation of esports betting still depended on state law. Some betting houses in Nevada, where sports betting is already exempted under PASPA, classify esports as non-competitive "other events" similar to the selection of the [[Heisman Trophy]] winner or [[NFL Draft]] to be legal.<ref name="wapost betting">{{cite web | url = Esports bookmaking? Globally, it’s already a billion-dollar gambling industry | first = Noah | last = Smith | date = 6 April 2018 | accessdate = 8 June 2018 | work = [[The Washington Post]] }}</ref> Other companies established in the United States allow for legal esports betting for international users but are restricted from Americans. Nevada legalized esports gambling in June 2017, classifying esports alongside competitive sports and dog racing.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.espn.com/chalk/story/_/id/19512317/chalk-nevada-governor-approves-esports-betting-bill | title = Nevada governor approves esports betting bill | first = Jacob | last = Wolf | date = 2 June 2017 | accessdate = 8 June 2018 | work = [[ESPN]] }}</ref>
With the [[Supreme Court of the United States]]'s ruling in ''[[Murphy v. National Collegiate Athletic Association]]'' in May 2018, PASPA was found unconstitutional, as the Court ruled that the federal government cannot limit states from regulating [[sports betting]]. This created the potential for legalized esports-based betting in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamesn.com/esports-betting | title = Esports betting may soon become legal in several American states | first = Ali | last= Jones | date = 17 May 2018 | accessdate=8 June 2018 | work = [[PCGamesN]] }}</ref> However, New Jersey, the state at the center of the Supreme Court case, passed its bill to legalize sports gambling but restricted gambling on esports to only international competitions where most players are over 18 years of age.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://compete.kotaku.com/new-jersey-added-a-last-minute-esports-betting-ban-and-1826678155 | title = New Jersey Added A Last-Minute Esports Betting Ban And No One Knows Why | first = Maddy | last= Myers | date = 8 June 2018 | accessdate = 8 June 2018 | work = [[Kotaku]] }}</ref>
Without PASPA, interstate gambling on esports would be still be limited by the [[Federal Wire Act]], preventing users from betting on national esports events outside of the state.<ref name="wapost betting"/>
===Data analytics and machine learning=== With the growing popularity of [[machine learning]] in data analytics,{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} esports has been the focus of several software programs that analyze the plethora of game data available. Based on the huge number of matches played on a daily basis globally ([[League of Legends]] alone had a reported 100 million active monthly players worldwide in 2016<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.riftherald.com/2016/9/13/12865314/monthly-lol-players-2016-active-worldwide | title = Number of players of selected eSports games worldwide as of August 2017 (in million) | date = 13 September 2016 | accessdate=12 August 2018 | work = [[Rift Herald]] }}</ref> and an average of 27 million League of Legends games played per day reported in 2014 <ref>Sheer, Ian (January 27, 2014). "Player Tally for 'League of Legends' Surges". Wsj.com. Archived from the original on January 30, 2014. Retrieved January 31, 2014.</ref>), these games can be used for applying big-data machine learning platforms. Several games make their data publicly available, so websites aggregate the data into easy-to-visualize graphs and statistics. In addition, several programs use machine learning tools to predict the win probability of a match based on various factors, such as team composition.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.06498.pdf | title = Win Prediction in Esports: Mixed-Rank Match Prediction in Multi-player Online Battle Arena Games | date = 17 November 2017 | accessdate=12 August 2018}}</ref> In 2018, the [[DotA]] team [[Team Liquid]] partnered with a software company to allow players and coaches to predict the team's success rate in each match and provide advice on what needs to be changed to improve performance.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://news.abs-cbn.com/sports/05/10/18/dota-analytics-big-data-meets-e-sports-in-software-giant-deal-with-team-liquid | title = ‘DOTA analytics’: Big data meets e-sports in software giant deal with Team Liquid | date = 10 May 2018 | accessdate=12 August 2018 | work = [[ABC-CBN News]] }}</ref>
==Media coverage== {{multiple image|image1=The International 2018 (30302304258).jpg|image2=The International 2018 (30302303908).jpg|footer=As with traditional sporting events, larger eSport events, such as [[The International (Dota 2)|The International]], usually feature live pre- and post-game discussion by a panel of analysts (''top''), with in-match casting being done by [[play-by-play]] and [[color commentators]] (''bottom'').|width=250|direction=vertical|align=right}}
===News reporting=== The main medium for esports coverage is the [[Internet]]. In the mid-2010s, mainstream sports and news reporting websites, such as ''[[ESPN]]'', ''[[Yahoo!]]'', ''[[Sport1 (Germany)|Sport1]]'', ''[[Kicker (magazine)|Kicker]]'', and ''[[Aftonbladet]]'' started dedicated esports coverage.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dave |first1=Paresh |title=ESPN.com to cover e-sports with same 'rigor' as it does the big leagues |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-espn-esports-20160113-story.html |website=LA Times |accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Yahoo Launches New Experience Dedicated to Esports |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/yahoo-launches-experience-dedicated-esports-050000022.html |website=Yahoo |accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> esports tournaments commonly use commentators or casters to provide live commentary of games in progress, similar to a traditional [[sports commentator]]. For popular casters, providing commentary for esports can be a full-time position by itself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/features/2013/7/16/4503412/starcraft-commentators-tastosis |title=How two StarCraft commentators became stars |publisher=Polygon |author=Tracey Lien |date=16 July 2013 |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref> Prominent casters for ''StarCraft II'' include [[Dan "Artosis" Stemkoski]] and [[Nick "Tasteless" Plott]].
In 2018, the [[Associated Press]]' [[AP Stylebook]] officially began spelling the word as "esports", dropping support for both the capital "S" and the dash between "e" and "sports" styles, similar to how "[[e-mail]]" transformed with common usage to "email".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://dotesports.com/culture/ap-style-esports-13789 |title=Goodbye eSports: The 2017 AP Style Guide will settle the esports spelling debate once and for all |publisher=Dot Esports |author=Justin Binkowski |date=25 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://esports.yahoo.com/its-official-the-ap-style-guide-spells-it-esports-not-esports-e-sports-or-esports-233434245.html |title=It’s official: The AP Style guide spells it ‘esports’, not ‘eSports’, ‘e-sports’, or ‘Esports’ |publisher=Yahoo Esports |author=Taylor Cocke |date=24 March 2017}}</ref> Richard Tyler Blevins, better known as "[[Ninja (streamer)|Ninja]]", became the first professional gamer to appear in a cover story for a major sports magazine when he appeared in the September 2018 issue of ''[[ESPN The Magazine]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vg247.com/2018/09/18/ninja-espn-magazine-cover/ | title = Fortnite streamer Ninja graces cover of latest ESPN magazine – a first for professional gaming | first = Stephany | last = Nunnelley | date = September 18, 2018 | accessdate = September 18, 2018 | work = [[VG247]] }}</ref>
===Internet live streaming=== Many esports events are [[streamed]] online to viewers over the internet. With the shutdown of the Own3d streaming service in 2013, [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]] is by far the most popular streaming service for esports, competing against other providers such as Hitbox.tv, Azubu, and [[YouTube Gaming]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.redbull.com/en/games/stories/1331687386855/hitbox-vs-twitch-which-is-better |title=How Hitbox plans to take on Twitch |author=Jon Partridge |publisher=RedBull |date=29 October 2014 |accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamingsoul.com/pcmac/own3d-is-shutting-down-twitch-tv-declared-winner/ |title=Own3D is Shutting Down. Twitch TV Declared Winner. |publisher=GamingSoul |author=Erik Cloutier |date=29 January 2013 |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> Dreamhack Winter 2011 reached 1.7 million unique viewers on Twitch.<ref name="dreamhackrecord">{{cite web |url=http://www.dreamhack.se/dhw11/2011/12/06/dreamhack-and-twitch-tv-announce-record-breaking-online-viewership/ |title=Dreamhack and Twitch.TV Announce Record-Breaking Online Viewership |publisher=Dreamhack}}</ref> While coverage of live events usually brings in the largest viewership counts, the recent popularization of streaming services has allowed individuals to broadcast their own gameplay independent of such events as well. Individual broadcasters can enter an agreement with Twitch or Hitbox in which they receive a portion of the advertisement revenue from commercials which run on the stream they create.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2013/02/05/talking-livestreams-esports-and-the-future-of-entertainment-with-twitch-tv/ |title=Talking Livestreams, eSports and the Future of Entertainment with Twitch |author=Paul Tassi |publisher=Forbes |date=2 May 2013 |accessdate=16 September 2013}}</ref>
Another major streaming platform was [[Major League Gaming]]'s MLG.tv.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tv.majorleaguegaming.com/ |title=MLG Streaming Platform |publisher=Major League Gaming |accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref> The network, which specializes in ''[[Call of Duty]]'' content but hosts a range of gaming titles, has seen increasing popularity, with 1376% growth in MLG.tv viewership in Q1 of 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.majorleaguegaming.com/news/nadeshot-joins-mlg-tv-streaming-platform-apps-for-android-and-ios-released |title=1376% Growth in MLG.tv Viewership in Q1 |publisher=Major League Gaming |date=10 April 2014 |accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref> The 2014 ''[[Call of Duty: Ghosts]]'' broadcast at [[Major League Gaming|MLG]]'s X Games event drew over 160,000 unique viewers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esportsmax.com/events/mlg-championship-2014-anaheim-ca |title=MLG Championship 2014 - Anaheim, CA |publisher=Esports Maxl |date=22 June 2014 |accessdate=28 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627135654/http://www.esportsmax.com/events/mlg-championship-2014-anaheim-ca |archivedate=27 June 2014 }}</ref> The network, like Twitch, allows users to broadcast themselves playing games, though only select individuals can use the service. For several years, MLG.tv was the primary streaming platform for the ''[[Call of Duty]]'' professional scene; famous players such as [[NaDeSHoT]] and [[Scump]] have signed contracts with the company to use its streaming service exclusively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.majorleaguegaming.com/news/nadeshot-joins-mlg-tv-streaming-platform-apps-for-android-and-ios-released |title=Video Game Super Star "Nadeshot" Signs Exclusive Deal with Major League Gaming |publisher=Major League Gaming |date=10 April 2014 |accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref> In January 2016, MLG was acquired by [[Activision Blizzard]].<ref name="nyt-mlgbuy" />
[[YouTube]] also relaunched its livestreaming platform with a renewed focus on live gaming and esports specifically.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/youtube-google-esports-livestreaming/ |title=YouTube to relaunch livestreaming service with focus on esports and gaming |first=Richard |last=Lewis |website=The Daily Dot |date=24 March 2015 |accessdate=4 May 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414052737/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/youtube-google-esports-livestreaming/ |archivedate=14 April 2015 }}</ref> For [[The International 2014]], coverage was also simulcast on [[ESPN]]'s streaming service [[ESPN3]].<ref name="polygon-espn3dota">{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/7/17/5913301/the-international-dota-2-championships-espn3 |title=The International Dota 2 championships will be watchable on ESPN3 |work=Polygon |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref> In December 2016, [[Riot Games]] announced a deal with [[MLB Advanced Media]]'s technology division BAM Tech for the company to distribute and monetize broadcasts of ''League of Legends'' events through 2023. BAM Tech will pay Riot at least $300 million per-year, and split advertising revenue.<ref name="polygon-bamtechaol">{{cite web |title=League of Legends’ maker inks rich broadcast contract, with an eye on premium content |url=http://www.polygon.com/2016/12/18/13998614/league-of-legends-premium-tv-service-mlb |website=Polygon |publisher=Vox Media |accessdate=18 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="wsj-lolmlb">{{cite web |title=‘League of Legends’ E-Sports Contests Lure Newest Fan: Major League Baseball |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/league-of-legends-e-sports-contests-lure-newest-fan-major-league-baseball-1481889603 |website=Wall Street Journal |accessdate=18 December 2016}}</ref>
===Television=== [[File:Televised Star Craft.jpg|thumb|left|''[[StarCraft]]'' match televised on [[MBCGame]] in [[Seoul]], South Korea]] Especially since the popularization of streaming in esports, organizations no longer prioritize television coverage, preferring online streaming websites such as [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]]. [[Ongamenet]] continues to broadcast as an esports channel in South Korea, but [[MBCGame]] was taken off the air in 2012. Riot Games' Dustin Beck stated that "TV's not a priority or a goal",<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danieltack/2013/09/04/riot-games-league-of-legends-and-the-future-of-esports/ |title=Riot Games, 'League of Legends', And The Future Of eSports |publisher=Forbes |author=Daniel Tack |date=4 September 2013 |accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> and DreamHack's Tomas Hermansson said "esports have [been proven] to be successful on internet streaming [services]."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gosugamers.net/starcraft2/news/25446-dreamhack-partners-with-mtg-for-esports-studio-in-stockholm |title=DreamHack partners with MTG for eSports studio in Stockholm |publisher=Gosu Gamers |author=Radoslav "Nydra" Kolev |date=25 September 2013 |accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref>
On the night before the finals of [[The International 2014]] in August, [[ESPN3]] broadcast a half-hour special profiling the tournament.<ref name="polygon-espn3dota"/> In 2015, ESPN2 broadcast ''Heroes of the Dorm'', the grand finals of the ''[[Heroes of the Storm]]'' collegiate tournament. The first-place team from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] received tuition for each of the teams players, paid for by Blizzard and Tespa.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Molina |first1=Brett |title=Blizzard unveils "Heroes of the Storm" tournament |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/gaming/2015/03/06/heroes-of-the-storm-tournament/24493989/ |website=USA Today |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> The top four teams won gaming equipment and new computers. This was the first time an eSport had ever been broadcast on a major American television network. The broadcast was an attempt to broaden the appeal of esports by reaching viewers who would not normally come across it. However, the broadcast was met with a few complaints. Those living outside of the United States were unable to view the tournament. Additionally, the tournament could not be viewed online via streams, cutting off a large portion of viewers from the main demographic in the process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/heroes-of-the-dorm-finals-were-a-success-story-for-esports/ |title=Heroes of the Dorm finals were a success story for esports |website=[[PCGamer]] |first=Tom |last=Marks |date=27 April 2015 |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>
In September 2015, [[Turner Broadcasting System|Turner Broadcasting]] partnered with [[William Morris Endeavor|WME/IMG]]. In December 2015, the partnered companies announced two seasons of the [[ELeague]], a [[Counter-Strike: Global Offensive]] league based in North America including 15 teams from across the world competing for a $1,200,000 prize pool each 10-week season. The tournament, filmed at Turner's studios in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], is simultaneously streamed on online streaming websites and [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] on Friday nights.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.e-league.com/ |title=ELeague Official Website |date=|access-date = |website= |publisher= |last= |first=}}</ref>
In January 2016, [[Activision Blizzard]], publishers of the ''Call of Duty'' and ''StarCraft'' series, acquired [[Major League Gaming]]. In an interview with ''[[The New York Times]]'' about the purchase, Activision Blizzard CEO [[Robert Kotick]] explained that the company was aspiring to create a U.S. cable network devoted to esports, which he described as "the ESPN of video games". He felt that higher quality productions, more in line with those of traditional sports telecasts, could help to broaden the appeal of esports to advertisers. Activision Blizzard had hired former ESPN and [[NFL Network]] executive [[Steve Bornstein]] to be CEO of the company's esports division.<ref name="nyt-mlgbuy">{{cite web |title=Activision Buys Major League Gaming to Broaden Role in E-Sports |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/05/technology/activision-buys-major-league-gaming-to-broaden-role-in-e-sports.html?smid=tw-share&_r=1 |website=The New York Times |accessdate=5 January 2016}}</ref>
[[TV 2 (Norway)|TV 2]], the largest private television broadcaster in [[Norway]], broadcasts esports across the country. TV 2 partnered with local Norwegian organization House of Nerds to bring a full season of esports competition with an initial lineup of ''Counter-Strike: Global Offensive'', ''League of Legends'', and ''StarCraft II''.<ref>Commercial broadcast company TV 2 is partnering with local Norwegian organization House of Nerds to bring a full season of esports competition to domestic airwaves.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/esports-norway-tv2/ |title=Esports are coming to television in Norway |website=[[The Daily Dot]] |first=Jared |last=Wynne |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=7 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414000347/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/esports-norway-tv2/ |archivedate=14 April 2015 }}</ref>
In April 2016, [[Big Ten Network]] announced a collaboration with Riot to hold an invitational ''League of Legends'' competition between two universities from the collegiate [[Big Ten Conference]], as part of Riot's collegiate championships at [[PAX East]].<ref name="sbnation-btnlol">{{cite web |title=Riot Games and Big Ten Network partner for televised Ohio State vs. Michigan State League of Legends match |url=https://www.sbnation.com/2016/4/14/11414260/ohio-state-michigan-state-league-of-legends-big-ten-network |publisher=[[SB Nation]] |accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref> On 17 January 2017, Big Ten Network and Riot announced that it would hold a larger season of conference competition involving 10 Big Ten schools.<ref name="nyt-big10lol">{{cite web |title=Big Ten Universities Entering a New Realm: E-Sports |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/19/sports/big-ten-is-entering-a-new-realm-e-sports.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
[[Nielsen Holdings]], a global information company known for tracking viewership for television and other media, announced in August 2017 that it would launch Nielsen esports, a division devoted to providing similar viewership and other consumer research data around esports, forming an advisory board with members from [[ESL (company)|ESL]], [[Activision Blizzard]], [[Twitch.tv]], [[YouTube]], [[ESPN]], and [[FIFA]] to help determine how to track and monitor audience sizes for eSport events.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/nielsen-esports-company |title=The company that governs TV ratings just started an esports organisation |first=Ali |last=Jones |date=18 August 2017 |accessdate=18 August 2017 |work=[[PCGamesN]]}}</ref>
In July 2018, on the first day of the inaugural [[2018 Overwatch League season]] playoffs, Blizzard and [[Disney]] announced a multi-year deal that gave Disney and its networks [[ESPN]] and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] broadcast rights to the Overwatch League and [[Overwatch World Cup]], starting with the playoffs and continuing with future events.<ref name="OWL on TV">{{cite web | url = http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/24062274/overwatch-league-comes-espn-disney-abc | title = Overwatch League comes to ESPN, Disney and ABC | date = 11 July 2018 | accessdate = 11 July 2018 | work = [[ESPN]] }}</ref>

page.title: Failure modes, effects, and diagnostic analysis

revision.text:
'''Failure modes, effects, and diagnostic analysis''' ('''FMEDA''') is a systematic analysis technique to obtain subsystem / product level failure rates, failure modes and diagnostic capability. The FMEDA technique considers: * All components of a design, * The functionality of each component, * The failure modes of each component, * The effect of each component failure mode on the product functionality, * The ability of any automatic diagnostics to detect the failure, * The design strength (de-rating, safety factors) and * The operational profile (environmental stress factors).
Given a component database calibrated with field failure data that is reasonably accurate <ref>{{cite manual | last = | first = | author-link = |author2= | title = Electrical & Mechanical Component Reliability Handbook | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = exida | year = 2006 | url = http://www.exida.com | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> , the method can predict product level failure rate and failure mode data for a given application. The predictions have been shown to be more accurate <ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = William M. | author-link = |author2= Iwan van Beurden | title = Combining field failure data with new instrument design margins to predict failure rates for SIS Verification | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = Proceedings of the 2014 International Symposium - BEYOND REGULATORY COMPLIANCE, MAKING SAFETY SECOND NATURE, Hilton College Station-Conference Center, College Station, Texas | year = 2014 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> than field warranty return analysis or even typical field failure analysis given that these methods depend on reports that typically do not have sufficient detail information in failure records.<ref>W. M. Goble, "Field Failure Data – the Good, the Bad and the Ugly," exida, Sellersville,PA [http://www.exida.com/resources/whitepapers.asp]</ref>
The name was given by Dr. William M. Goble in 1994 to the technique that had been in development since 1988 by Dr. Goble and other engineers now at exida.
== Antecedents ==
A [[failure modes and effects analysis]], FMEA, is a structured qualitative analysis of a system, subsystem, process, design or function to identify potential failure modes, their causes and their effects on (system) operation. The concept and practice of performing a FMEA, has been around in some form since the 1960s. The practice was first formalized in 1970s with the development of US MIL STD 1629/1629A. In early practice its use was limited to select applications and industries where cost of failure was particularly high. The primary benefits were to qualitatively evaluate the safety and reliability of a system, determine unacceptable failure modes, identify potential design improvements, plan maintenance activities and help understand system operation in the presence of potential faults. The [[failure modes, effects and criticality analysis]] (FMECA) was introduced to address a primary barrier to effective use of the detailed FMEA results by the addition of a criticality metric. This allowed users of the analysis to quickly focus on the most important failure modes/effects in terms of risk. This allowed prioritization to drive improvements based on cost / benefit comparisons.
== Development ==
The FMEDA technique was developed in the late 1980s by exida engineers based in part on a paper in the 1984 [[RAMS]] Symposium.<ref>Collett, R. E. and Bachant, P. W., "Integration of BIT Effectiveness with FMECA," 1984 Proceedings of the Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, NY: New York, [[IEEE]], 1984.</ref> The initial FMEDA added two additional pieces of information to the FMEA analysis process. The first piece of information added in an FMEDA is the quantitative failure data (failure rates and the distribution of failure modes) for all components being analyzed. The second piece of information added to an FMEDA is the probability of the system or subsystem to detect internal failures via automatic on-line diagnostics. This is crucial to achieving and maintaining reliability in increasing complex systems and for systems that may not be fully exercising all functionality under normal circumstances such as a low demand Emergency Shutdown System, ESD System. There is a clear need for a measurement of automatic diagnostic capability. This was recognized in the late 1980s <ref>H.A. Amer,and E. J. McCluskey, "Weighted Coverage in Fault-Tolerant Systems," 1987 Proceedings of the Annual Reliability and Maintainabiltiy Symposium, NY: NY, [[IEEE]], 1987.</ref> In that context the principles and basic methods for the modern FMEDA were first documented in the book ''Evaluating Control System Reliability''.<ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = William M. | author-link = |author2= | title = Evaluating Control Systems Reliability, Techniques and Applications | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = [[International Society of Automation|ISA]] | year = 1992 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> The actual term FMEDA was first used in 1994 <ref>{{cite manual | last = | first = | author-link = |author2= | title = FMEDA Analysis of CDM (Critical Discrete Module) – QUADLOG | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = Moore Products Company | year = 1994 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> and after further refinement the methods were published in the late 1990s.<ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = W.M. | author-link = |author2= | title = The Use and Development of Quantitative Reliability and Safety Analysis in New Product Design | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = University Press, Eindhoven University of Technology, Netherlands | year = 1998 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref><ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = W.M. | author-link = |author2= | title = Control Systems Safety Evaluation and Reliability | section = | sectionurl = | version = 2 | publisher = ISA | year = 1998 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref><ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = W.M. | author-link = |author2= A. C. Brombacher | title = Using a Failure Modes, Effects and Diagnostic Analysis (FMEDA) to Measure Diagnostic Coverage in Programmable Electronic Systems | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = Reliability Engineering and System Safety, Vol. 66, No. 2 | year = 1999 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> The method was explained to members of the IEC 61508 committee in the late 90s and included in the standard as a method of determining failure rate, failure mode and diagnostic coverage for products. FMEDA techniques have been further refined during the 2000s primarily during IEC 61508 preparation work. The key changes have been: 1. Use of Functional Failure Modes; 2. Mechanical Component Usage; 3. Prediction of manual proof test effectiveness; and 4. Prediction of product useful life. With these changes, the FMEDA technique has matured to become more complete and useful.
== Functional failure mode analysis ==
Also in the early 2000s functional failure mode analysis was added to the FMEDA process by John C. Grebe. In early FMEDA work, component failure modes were mapped directly to "safe" or "dangerous" categories per IEC 61508. This was relatively easy since everything that was not "dangerous" was "safe." With multiple failure mode categories now existing, direct assignment became more difficult. In addition, it became clear that the category assignment might change if a product were used in different applications. With direct failure mode category assignment during the FMEDA, a new FMEDA was required for each new application or each variation in usage. Under the functional failure mode approach, the actual functional failure modes of the product are identified during an FMEA. During the detailed FMEDA, each component failure mode is mapped to a functional failure mode. The functional failure modes are then categorized according to product failure mode in a particular application. This eliminates the need for more detailed work when a new application is considered.
== Mechanical FMEDA Techniques ==
It became clear in the early 2000s that many products being used in safety critical applications had mechanical components. An FMEDA done without considering these mechanical components was incomplete, misleading, and potentially dangerous. The fundamental problem in using the FMEDA technique was the lack of a mechanical component database that included part failure rates and failure mode distributions. Using a number of published reference sources, exida began development of a mechanical component database in 2003.<ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = William M. | author-link = |author2= | title = Accurate Failure Metrics for Mechanical Instruments | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = Proceedings of [[IEC 61508]] Conference, Germany: Augsberg, RWTUV | year = 2003 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> After a few years of research and refinement,<ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = William M. | author-link = |author2= J.V. Bukowski | title = Development of a Mechanical Component Failure Database | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = 2007 Proceedings of the Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium NY: NY, [[IEEE]] | year = 2007 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> the database has been published.<ref>{{cite manual | last = | first = | author-link = |author2= | title = Electrical & Mechanical Component Reliability Handbook | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = exida | year = 2006 | url = http://www.exida.com | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> This has allowed the FMEDA to be used on combination electrical / mechanical components and purely mechanical components.
== Manual Proof Test Effectiveness ==
The FMEDA can predict the effectiveness of any defined manual proof test in the same way it can predict automatic diagnostic coverage. An additional column is added to the FMEDA and probability of detection for each component failure mode is estimated. The cumulative effectiveness of the proof test is calculated in the same way as automatic diagnostic coverage.
== Product Useful Life ==
As each component within a product is reviewed, those with a relatively short useful life span are identified. One example of this is an electrolytic capacitor. Many designs have a useful life limitation of 10 years. Since constant failure rates are only valid during the useful life period, this metric is valuable for interpreting FMEDA result limitations.
== The Future == [[File:FMEDA Comparison Studies.png|thumb|right|FMEDA Comparison Studies]]
It is clear that further refinement of the component database with selective calibration to different operation profiles is needed. In addition, comparisons of FMEDA results with field failure studies, have shown that human factors, especially maintenance procedures, affect the failure rates and failure modes of products.
As more data becomes available, the component database can be refined and updated. After a few years of research and refinement,<ref>{{cite manual | last = Goble | first = William M. | author-link = |author2= J.V. Bukowski | title = Development of a Mechanical Component Failure Database | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = 2007 Proceedings of the Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium NY: NY, [[IEEE]] | year = 2007 | url = | format = | id = | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> the database has been published <ref>{{cite manual | last = | first = | author-link = |author2= | title = Electrical & Mechanical Component Reliability Handbook, Third Edition | section = | sectionurl = | version = | publisher = exida | year = 2008 | url = http://www.exida.com | format = | isbn = 978-1-934977-04-0 | accessdate = | quote = | page = | pages = }}</ref> as required by new technology and new knowledge. The success of the FMEDA technique is supplying needed data in a relatively accurate way has allowed the probabilistic, performance approach to design to work.

{{short description|annual hacker event hosted by O'Reilly Media}} {{notability|Events|date=September 2017}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2008}} [[File:Tim O'Reilly in Foo China 2007.JPG|thumb|[[Tim O'Reilly]] in Foo China 2007]] '''Foo Camp''' is an annual [[Hacker (programmer subculture)|hacker]] event hosted by publisher [[O'Reilly Media]]. O'Reilly describes it as "the wiki of conferences", where the program is developed by the attendees at the event, using big whiteboard schedule templates that can be rewritten or overwritten by attendees to optimize the schedule; this type of event is sometimes called an [[unconference]].
The event started as a joke between [[Tim O'Reilly]] and Sara Winge, O'Reilly's VP of Corporate Communications. Sara had always wanted to run a [[Foobar|''foo bar'']], an open bar for ''Friends of O'Reilly'', at one of O'Reilly's conferences. That joke morphed into a brainstorm after the dot com bust left O'Reilly with lots of unused office space in its new buildings, creating the opportunity for Foo Camp. The first FOO Camp was held in August, 2003, and had approximately 200 attendees.<ref>{{cite web|last=Battelle|first=John|title=When geeks go camping, ideas hatch|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/TECH/ptech/01/09/bus2.feat.geek.camp/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=30 December 2013|date=10 January 2004|df=dmy-all}}</ref> There was eventually a Foo Bar at the camp.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Watt|first1=Justin C.|title=FOO Camp - Justinsomnia|url=http://justinsomnia.org/2005/08/foo-camp/|website=justinsomnia.org|accessdate=March 15, 2018|language=en|date=2005|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Tim O'Reilly describes the goal of his company as "changing the world by spreading the knowledge of innovators." Foo Camp has evolved into an important mechanism for finding those innovators. O'Reilly asks attendees to nominate new and interesting people to be invited to future camps.
==Other events== In 2005, a complementary alternative [[BarCamp]] was created by a past attendee of Foo Camp and a few individuals who were interested in organizing their own version of Foo Camp, and hosted at the [[Socialtext]] offices in [[Palo Alto]], [[California]], by Socialtext founder [[Ross Mayfield]], with an open invitation to anyone who wanted to join.
Since February 2007, former O'Reilly employee Nathan Torkington has hosted an annual Kiwi Foo Camp in [[Warkworth, New Zealand]]<ref name=kiwifoo_website>{{cite web|title=Kiwi Foo Camp Website|url=http://baacamp.org/|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://computerworld.co.nz/news.nsf/news/1956694458963284CC2573E9000D8991|title=Geeks gather to share, network and play|date=13 February 2008|author=John Ballinger|publisher=Computerworld New Zealand|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210052054/http://computerworld.co.nz/news.nsf/news/1956694458963284CC2573E9000D8991|archivedate=10 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
O'Reilly has since held a series of topical Foo Camps at Google Headquarters, including [[Science Foo Camp]], Collective Intelligence Foo Camp, Social Graph Foo Camp, and others. In December 2010, O'Reilly co-organized NewsFoo with Google and the [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation|Knight Foundation]] at the Walter Cronkite School of Journalism and Mass Communication in Phoenix Arizona.
In 2011, O'Reilly announced the Health Foo on the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Blog.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tim O'Reilly to Host 'Unconference' for Health, Tech Leaders|url=http://www.rwjf.org/en/blogs/pioneering-ideas/2010/12/tim-oreilly-to-host-unconference-for-health-tech-leaders.html|website=RWJF|accessdate=March 15, 2018|language=en|date=2 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In February 2018, O’Reilly, [[Facebook]] and [[SAGE Publications]] held the first Social Science Foo Camp at Facebook in [[Menlo Park, California|Menlo Park]], California.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kecskemethy|first1=Tom|title=Ignorance and Interdisciplinary Work: Field Notes from the Social Science Foo Camp|url=https://ocean.sagepub.com/blog/2018/3/7/ignorance-and-interdisciplinary-work-field-notes-from-the-social-science-foo-camp|website=SAGE Ocean|accessdate=March 15, 2018|date=March 7, 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
